revision.text:
{{redirect|12/12/12|the film|12/12/12 (film)}} {{confused|2012 phenomenon}} {{use mdy dates|date=December 2012}} {{infobox music festival | music_festival_name = 12-12-12: The Concert for Sandy Relief | image = Concertforsandy.jpg | caption = | alt = | founders = [[James L. Dolan]], [[John Sykes (American businessman)|John Sykes]] and [[Harvey Weinstein]] | location = [[Madison Square Garden]]
[[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], United States | dates = December 12, 2012 | genre = [[Benefit concert]] }} '''''12-12-12: The Concert for Sandy Relief''''' was a [[benefit concert]] that took place on December 12, 2012, at [[Madison Square Garden]] in [[New York City]]. The concert was held in response to [[Hurricane Sandy]], which devastated portions of the [[Northeastern United States]], the Caribbean and the Mid-Atlantic in late October 2012 and cost an estimated $60 billion in damage in the United States. The concert was broadcast live via television, radio, movie theaters and the Internet, and released on DVD and CD. A [[12-12-12|documentary film]] was also made about the concert. Proceeds from the event were collected by the [[Robin Hood Foundation|Robin Hood Relief Fund]] to benefit victims of the hurricane in [[New York (state)|New York]], [[New Jersey]] and [[Connecticut]]. Many famous performers took part in the charity event, including [[The Who]], [[Bruce Springsteen]], [[Alicia Keys]], [[Bon Jovi]], [[Eric Clapton]], [[Billy Joel]], [[The Rolling Stones]], [[Roger Waters]], [[Chris Martin]], [[Michael Stipe]], [[Kanye West]], [[Eddie Vedder]], and, for the first time in eighteen years, the surviving members of [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]] ([[Dave Grohl]], [[Krist Novoselic]] and touring member [[Pat Smear]]) who performed together in a collaboration with [[Paul McCartney]] during his show-closing set.{{cite web|title=Paul McCartney to Front Nirvana Reunion at 12-12-12 Concert|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/paul-mccartney-to-perform-with-dave-grohl-and-friends-at-12-12-12-20121212|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|accessdate=26 March 2013}}{{cite web|last=Greene|first=Andy|title=Nirvana-Paul McCartney Song Stems From Dave Grohl's 'Sound City' Documentary|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/nirvana-paul-mccartney-song-stems-from-dave-grohls-sound-city-documentary-20121213|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|accessdate=26 March 2013}} ==Background== The benefit concert was first announced in mid-November 2012 and that the producers behind 2001's ''[[The Concert for New York City]]'' would also produce the Hurricane Sandy benefit which quickly attracted many big names from the music industry. The venue and on sale date for tickets were announced in early December. Madison Square Garden had originally been reserved on December 12 for a [[New York Rangers]] game against the [[Montreal Canadiens]] that was among the many canceled due to the [[2012 NHL lockout]].{{cite news|author = Staff | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/capitals/a-look-at-the-88th-day-of-the-nhl-lockout/2012/12/12/bce19626-44c2-11e2-8c8f-fbebf7ccab4e_story.html|title=A Look at the 88th Day of the NHL Lockout|date=December 12, 2012|publisher=Associated Press (via ''[[The Washington Post]]'') |accessdate=December 13, 2012}} Proceeds from the event went to the [[Robin Hood Foundation|Robin Hood Relief Fund]] and benefit victims of the hurricane in areas most impacted, especially [[New York (state)|New York]], [[New Jersey]] and [[Connecticut]].Staff (December 4, 2012). [http://www.pollstar.com/news_article.aspx?ID=803505 "12-12-12 Sandy Benefit to Be Aired on 34 Outlets"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150514092457/http://www.pollstar.com/news_article.aspx?ID=803505 |date=May 14, 2015 }}. [[Associated Press]] (via ''[[Pollstar]]''). Retrieved December 13, 2012. More than $30 million was raised through ticket sales alone. ==Tickets== Tickets for the event went on sale through [[Ticketmaster]] on December 3, 2012, at noon though Chase Bank customers were allowed to buy tickets at 9 a.m. Tickets quickly sold out in minutes.{{cite web | author = Staff | date = December 12, 2012 | url=http://entertainment.time.com/2012/12/12/watch-live-the-12-12-12-sandy-relief-concert-starring-springsteen-mccartney-and-the-stones/ | title=Watch Live: The 12-12-12 Sandy Relief Concert Starring Springsteen, McCartney and the Stones | work = [[Time (magazine)|Time]] | accessdate=December 13, 2012}} The face-value of tickets ranged from $150 to $2,500,{{cite web | author = Bauder, David | date = December 12, 2012 | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/12/12/12-12-12-concert-hurricane-sandy_n_2286723.html | title=12-12-12 Concert For Hurricane Sandy Victims Includes Music Royalty | work = [[The Huffington Post]] | accessdate=December 13, 2012}} with organizers saying all proceeds would go to the [[Robin Hood Foundation]].{{cite web| author = Brown, Stephen Rex | date = December 12, 2012 | url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/scalpers-making-concert-article-1.1218497| work = [[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] |title=Ticket Scalpers Making Big Bucks Off 12/12/12 Concert to Benefit Hurricane Sandy Victims – Online Ticket Resale Sites Are Busy with $10,000 Seats | accessdate = December 13, 2012}} Like most concerts with high demands for tickets, scalpers were able to buy up tickets and within minutes of the concert selling out were already available for re-sale at much higher prices on various sites, including [[StubHub]]. By December 7, 2012, tickets for the floor in front of the stage were listed for as much as $48,000 while those in the upper level were going for $525 to $3,000. Producers of the event urged people to not buy from these secondary websites because the money no longer goes to charity. [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[Charles E. Schumer]] sent a letter to StubHub and three other major online ticket exchanges, urging them to not allow sellers to profit from the demand for the concert stating that "Every dollar spent for these concert tickets should go to help the victims of Superstorm Sandy, not to line the pockets of unscrupulous scalpers”. A spokesman for StubHub, Glenn Lehrman, said it did not have the technology to require sellers to give their profits to charity. StubHub gave its commissions of more than $500,000 to the charity. Jacqueline Peterson, a spokeswoman for Ticketmaster, which handled the initial ticket sales, said her company had evidence that scalpers had used computer programs to snap up large numbers of tickets for resale. She said Ticketmaster had blocked thousands of sales to buyers that it identified as using these programs. Among the recipients of Schumer's letter were TicketMaster's in-house resale marketplaces, [[TicketsNow]] and [[TicketExchange]]; however, Peterson said that 12-12-12 tickets were not being allowed on those sites. [[TicketLiquidator]], another secondary re-sale website, also said that it had declined to carry tickets for the concert.[[James C. McKinley, Jr.|McKinliney, Jr., James C.]] (December 7, 2012). [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/08/arts/music/producers-of-12-12-12-benefit-concert-assail-scalpers.html?partner=rss&emc=rss "Benefit's Producers Condemn Scalpers"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. Retrieved December 12, 2012. There were also some incidents of counterfeit tickets.{{cite web|url=http://www.insideedition.com/investigative/5496-inside-edition-investigates-counterfeit-tickets |title=INSIDE EDITION Investigates Counterfeit Tickets |work=Inside Edition |date=December 12, 2012 |accessdate=December 15, 2012}} ==Broadcast== The concert was simulcast live on 39 U.S. television stations, including [[HBO]], [[AMC (TV channel)|AMC]], [[Showtime (TV channel)|Showtime]] and [[AXS TV]] and on more than 20 international television networks.Staff (undated). [http://www.121212concert.org/broadcast#section-3 "US Television Channels"] {{Webarchive|url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20121212104739/http://www.121212concert.org/broadcast#section-3 |date=December 12, 2012 }}. 12-12-12: The Concert for Sandy Relief. Retrieved December 13, 2012. It was also streamed on over twenty-five websites,{{cite web | author = Deutsch, Lindsay | date = December 12, 2012 | url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/music/2012/12/11/sandy-relief-concert/1762049/ | title=Superstars Team Up for 12-12-12 Sandy Benefit | work = [[USA Today]] | accessdate=December 13, 2012}} including [[Fuse (TV channel)|Fuse.tv]], [[MTV|MTV.com]], [[AOL]], [[Yahoo!]], [[YouTube]], [[SiriusXM]], [[Hulu]], and [[Vevo]] and over fifty radio stations. Select movie theaters in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut displayed the concert as well.Staff (undated). [http://www.121212concert.org/watch "Where to Watch"] {{Webarchive|url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20121212104738/http://www.121212concert.org/watch |date=December 12, 2012 }}. 12-12-12: The Concert for Sandy Relief. Retrieved December 12, 2012. [[Ion Television]], [[Live Well Network]] and [[MundoFox]] were the only national over-the-air broadcasters to carry the concert. Locally, the [[Public Broadcasting System|PBS]] consortium [[WNET]]/[[WLIW]]/[[NJTV]] carried it on their stations, along with [[CBS Corporation|CBS]]'s [[WLNY]] (Channel 55) and [[WRNN-TV]] (Channel 48). [[WPSG]] (Channel 57) carried the show locally in [[Philadelphia]]. Event producers [[James L. Dolan|James Dolan]], [[John Sykes]] and [[Harvey Weinstein]] issued on December 3, 2012, the following joint statement: "The fact that so many major media companies are joining forces to distribute and stream this important event to homes worldwide will enable us to create a tremendous and unprecedented fundraising effort on a global scale to benefit the victims of this devastating storm."Joint press release (December 3, 2012). [http://globenewswire.com/news-release/2012/12/03/509172/10014390/en/12-12-12-Secures-Distribution-to-Over-One-Billion-People-Worldwide.html "12-12-12 Secures Distribution to Over One Billion People Worldwide"]. [[The Madison Square Garden Company]] and 12-12-12: The Concert for Sandy Relief (via [[GlobeNewswire]]). Retrieved December 13, 2012. While every major U.S. media company aired the benefit on at least one of their networks, none of the major over-the-air television networks including [[CBS]], [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]], [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] and [[NBC]] aired it, and neither did the major cable-news networks of [[CNN]], [[MSNBC]] and the [[Fox News Channel]]. [[Clear Channel]] broadcast the concert live on some of its radio stations across the country and also streamed it live on [[iHeartRadio]], its digital-radio service, and across the websites and [[Facebook]] pages of its 850 stations.{{cite web|title=Watch -- 12-12-12 website|url=http://www.121212concert.org/broadcast|accessdate=1 March 2013|archive-url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20121212104739/http://www.121212concert.org/broadcast|archive-date=December 12, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The concert also aired in conjunction with the [[NBA]]'s television and online streaming broadcasts in [[China]] and simulcast live on Clear Channel Outdoor digital billboards in [[Times Square]] and locations in [[London]] and [[Paris]].Giegerich, Liz (December 3, 2012). [http://southeast.patch.com/articles/tickets-now-on-sale-for-12-12-12-sandy-benefit-concert-at-msg "Tickets Now on Sale for 12-12-12 Sandy Benefit Concert at MSG{{spaced ndash}} A Star-Studded Music Event to Raise Money for the Robin Hood Relief Fund Will Be Held at MSG nNxt Wednesday"] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130131050709/http://southeast.patch.com/articles/tickets-now-on-sale-for-12-12-12-sandy-benefit-concert-at-msg |date=January 31, 2013 }}. [[Patch.com]]. Retrieved December 12, 2012. == Performers and segments== The event began at 7:30 pm and ran until 1:20 am. # Video montage of news coverage of the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy # [[Bruce Springsteen]] and the [[E Street Band]] ## "[[Land of Hope and Dreams]]" with portion of "[[People Get Ready (song)|People Get Ready]]" ## "Wrecking Ball" ## "[[My City of Ruins]]" with portion of "[[Jersey Girl (song)|Jersey Girl]]" ## "[[Born to Run (song)|Born to Run]]" (with [[Jon Bon Jovi]]) # [[Billy Crystal]] # [[Susan Sarandon]] # [[Roger Waters]] ## "[[In the Flesh?]]" ## "[[The Happiest Days of Our Lives]]" ## "[[Another Brick in the Wall|Another Brick in the Wall (Part 2)]]" (featuring a youth dance troupe) ## "The Ballad of [[Jean Charles de Menezes]]" ## "[[Money (Pink Floyd song)|Money]]" ## "[[Us and Them (song)|Us and Them]]" ## "[[Comfortably Numb]]" (with [[Eddie Vedder]]) # [[Adam Sandler]] and [[Paul Shaffer]] ## "Sandy Screw Ya" (comedic take on Sandy and New York set to "[[Hallelujah (Leonard Cohen song)|Hallelujah]]") # [[Brian Williams]] (with [[Ben Stiller]] and [[Whoopi Goldberg]]) # Billy Crystal # [[Kristen Stewart]] ## Video segment: Jon Bon Jovi in New Jersey # [[Bon Jovi]] ## "[[It's My Life (Bon Jovi song)|It's My Life]]" ## "[[Wanted Dead or Alive (Bon Jovi song)|Wanted Dead or Alive]]" ## "[[Who Says You Can't Go Home]]" (with Bruce Springsteen) ## "[[Livin' on a Prayer]]" (with ''[[a cappella]]'' intro) # Brian Williams (with [[Tony Danza]] and Whoopi Goldberg) # [[Jon Stewart]] # [[Eric Clapton]] ## "[[Nobody Knows You When You're Down and Out]]" ## "Got to Get Better in a Little While" ## "[[Cross Road Blues|Crossroads]]" # [[Chelsea Clinton]] ## Video segment of [[Team Rubicon]] in [[the Rockaways]] # [[Jimmy Fallon]] ## Video segment: Pastor Connie Hula # [[The Rolling Stones]] ## "[[You Got Me Rocking]]" ## "[[Jumpin' Jack Flash]]" # Video segment sponsored by [[Chase (bank)|Chase]] # [[Stephen Colbert]] # [[Sean Combs|Sean "Diddy" Combs]] and [[Olivia Wilde]] # [[Alicia Keys]] ## "[[Brand New Me (Alicia Keys song)|Brand New Me]]" ## "[[No One (Alicia Keys song)|No One]]" with several improvised interpolations of "Put your cellphones in the air" # Video segment sponsored by [[State Farm Insurance]] # [[Steve Buscemi]] ## Video segment: the Graybeards{{cite web|url=http://www.graybeards.com/ |title=Graybeards |publisher=Graybeards |date= |accessdate=December 15, 2012}} # [[The Who]] ## "[[Who Are You (song)|Who Are You]]" ## "[[Bell Boy (song)|Bell Boy]]" (featuring [[Keith Moon]] on vocals, via audio from ''[[Quadrophenia]]'' and archival video from [[The Valley (London)|Charlton]] performance of 18 May 1974) ## "[[Pinball Wizard]]" ## "[[See Me, Feel Me]]" ## "[[Baba O'Riley]]" ## "[[Love, Reign o'er Me]]" ## "Tea & Theatre" # Brian Williams (with [[Joe Pantoliano]] and [[James Gandolfini]]) # Video segment: Performers on the aftermath # Billy Crystal # [[News 12 New Jersey]] # Video segment: Neighbors in the aftermath, featuring Phyllis Puglia # [[Chris Rock]] # [[Kanye West]] (all songs performed as a medley) ## "[[Clique (song)|Clique]]" ## "[[Mercy (Kanye West song)|Mercy]]" ## "[[Power (Kanye West song)|Power]]" ## "[[Jesus Walks]]" ## "[[All of the Lights]]" ## "[[Run This Town]]" ## "[[Diamonds from Sierra Leone]]" ## "[[Diamonds (Rihanna song)|Diamonds Remix]]" ## "[[Touch the Sky (Kanye West song)|Touch the Sky]]" ## "[[Gold Digger (Kanye West song)|Gold Digger]]" ## "[[Good Life (Kanye West song)|Good Life]]" ## "[[Runaway (Kanye West song)|Runaway]]" ## "[[Stronger (Kanye West song)|Stronger]]" # Brian Williams (with [[Jack McBrayer]] and Jimmy Fallon) # [[Seth Meyers]] with [[Bobby Moynihan]] as "Drunk Uncle" # [[Jake Gyllenhaal]] with Patricia Farrell # [[Billy Joel]] ## "[[Miami 2017 (Seen the Lights Go Out on Broadway)]]" ## "[[Movin' Out (Anthony's Song)]]" ## "[[Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas]]" (portion) ## "[[New York State of Mind]]" ## "[[The River of Dreams]]" (featuring "Gloria") ## "[[You May Be Right (song)|You May Be Right]]" ## "[[Only the Good Die Young]]" # [[Blake Lively]] # [[Chris Martin]] of [[Coldplay]] ## "[[Viva la Vida]]" ## "[[Losing My Religion]]" (with [[Michael Stipe]] of [[R.E.M.]]) ## "[[Us Against the World (Coldplay song)|Us Against the World]]" # Brian Williams # [[Katie Holmes]] and [[Jason Sudeikis]] # Video segment: [[Red Hook, Brooklyn|Red Hook]] Rising # [[Leonardo DiCaprio]] (via video) # [[Jamie Foxx]], [[Quentin Tarantino]], and [[Christoph Waltz]] # [[Paul McCartney]] ## "[[Helter Skelter (song)|Helter Skelter]]" ## "[[Let Me Roll It]]" ## "[[Nineteen Hundred and Eighty-Five]]" ## "My Valentine" (with [[Diana Krall]]) ## "[[Blackbird (Beatles song)|Blackbird]]" ## "[[Cut Me Some Slack]]" (with [[Krist Novoselic]], [[Dave Grohl]] and [[Pat Smear]] of [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]]) ## "[[I've Got a Feeling]]" ## "[[Live and Let Die (song)|Live and Let Die]]" #Alicia Keys ## "[[Empire State of Mind (Part II) Broken Down]]"Bernstein, Scott (December 12, 2012). [http://www.glidemagazine.com/hiddentrack/12-12-12-the-concert-for-sandy-relief-live-updates-setlist-videos-photos "Watch: 12-12-12 The Concert For Sandy Relief + Live Updates"]. ''[[Glide Magazine]]''. Retrieved December 13, 2012. # Billy Crystal ==See also== {{portal|Hurricanes|Music|New York City}} * [[Hurricane Sandy]] * ''[[Hurricane Sandy: Coming Together]]'' * [[The Concert for New York City]] * [[From the Big Apple to the Big Easy]] * [[A Concert for Hurricane Relief]] * [[Mississippi Rising]] {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20121213133815/http://www.121212concert.org/ 121212concert.org], the concert's official website {{Hurricane Sandy series|state=collapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:12.12.12 - The Concert For Sandy Relief}} [[Category:2010s American television specials]] [[Category:2012 in American music]] [[Category:2012 in New York City]] [[Category:2012 television specials]] [[Category:Benefit concerts in the United States]] [[Category:Hurricane Sandy]] [[Category:Live television programs]] [[Category:Madison Square Garden]] [[Category:Music television specials]] [[Category:Simulcasts]] [[Category:December 2012 events]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox football match | title = 1966 FIFA World Cup Final | image = File:The Queen presents the 1966 World Cup to England Captain, Bobby Moore. (7936243534).jpg | imagesize = 250px | caption = Queen [[Elizabeth II]] presents England captain Bobby Moore with the [[FIFA World Cup trophy]] (Jules Rimet). | event = [[1966 FIFA World Cup]] | team1 = [[England national football team|England]] | team1association = {{flagicon|ENG|size=30px}} | team1score = 4 | team2 = [[Germany national football team|West Germany]] | team2association = {{flagicon|FRG|size=30px}} | team2score = 2 | details = After [[Overtime (sports)#Association football|extra time]] | date = 30 July 1966 | stadium = [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley Stadium]] | city = London | man_of_the_match1a = | referee = [[Gottfried Dienst]] ([[Swiss Football Association|Switzerland]]) | attendance = 96,924 | weather = | previous = [[1962 FIFA World Cup Final|1962]] | next = [[1970 FIFA World Cup Final|1970]] }} The '''1966 FIFA World Cup Final''' was the final match in the [[1966 FIFA World Cup]], the eighth [[association football|football]] [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]].[https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/worldcup/england1966/index.html "Hurst the hero for England in the home of football"]. FIFA. Retrieved 11 November 2014 The match was played by [[England national football team|England]] and [[Germany national football team|West Germany]] on 30 July 1966 at [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley Stadium]] in [[London]], and had an attendance of 96,924.{{cite web |url=https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/worldcup/england1966/matches/round=238/match=1633/index.html |title=1966 FIFA World Cup England |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=21 June 2014}} The British television audience peaked at 32.3 million viewers, making it the [[List of most-watched television broadcasts#Most watched special events|most watched television event ever]] in the United Kingdom.{{cite news |title=A riot of colour, emotion and memories: the World Cup stands alone in the field of sport|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/world-cup/world-cup-russia-2018-preview-lionel-messi-ronaldo-italia-90-98-england-brazil-germany-france-a8392211.html |accessdate=20 August 2018 |work=The Independent}} England won 4–2 [[extra time|after extra time]] to win the [[Jules Rimet Trophy]]. The England team became known as the "wingless wonders", on account of their then-unconventional narrow attacking formation, described at the time as a 4–4–2.{{cite web |url=https://www.fifa.com/news/y=2007/m=4/news=alf-ramsey-england-anonymous-hero-510253.html |title=Alf Ramsey – England's Anonymous Hero |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=28 January 2013}} The match is remembered for England's only World Cup trophy, [[Geoff Hurst]]'s [[hat-trick]] – the first, and to date, only one ever scored in a FIFA World Cup Final – and the controversial third goal awarded to England by referee [[Gottfried Dienst]] and linesman [[Tofiq Bahramov]]. == Road to the final == Both teams were strong throughout the tournament. Each won two and drew one of their three matches in the group stages. England did not concede a goal until their semi-final against Portugal. {| style="width:100%" |- |width=50% valign=top| ===England=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Team ! Score ! Venue ! Round |- | {{fb|URU}} | 0–0 | rowspan=5|[[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley Stadium]], London | Group 1 |- | {{fb|MEX|1934}} | 2–0 | Group 1 |- | {{fb|FRA}} | 2–0 | Group 1 |- | {{fb|ARG|alt}} | 1–0 | Quarter-final |- | {{fb|POR}} | 2–1 | Semi-final |} ===West Germany=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Team ! Score ! Venue ! Round |- | {{fb|SUI}} | 5–0 | [[Hillsborough Stadium]], [[Sheffield]] | Group 2 |- | {{fb|ARG|alt}} | 0–0 | rowspan=2|[[Villa Park]], [[Birmingham]] | Group 2 |- | {{fb|ESP|1945}} | 2–1 | Group 2 |- | {{fb|URU}} | 4–0 | [[Hillsborough Stadium]], [[Sheffield]] | Quarter-final |- | {{fb|URS|1955}} | 2–1 | [[Goodison Park]], [[Liverpool]] | Semi-final |} == Match == ===Summary=== ====Normal time==== England, managed by [[Alf Ramsey]] and captained by [[Bobby Moore]], won the toss and elected to kick off. After 12 minutes, [[Sigfried Held]] sent a cross into the English penalty area which [[Ray Wilson (English footballer)|Ray Wilson]] misheaded to [[Helmut Haller]], who got his shot on target. [[Jack Charlton]] and goalkeeper [[Gordon Banks]] failed to deal with the shot which went in making it 1–0 to West Germany. [[File:Old Wembley Stadium (external view).jpg|thumbnail|right|The original Wembley Stadium with its twin towers.]] In the 19th minute, [[Wolfgang Overath]] conceded a free kick, which Moore took immediately, floating a cross into the West German area, where [[Geoff Hurst]] rose unchallenged and levelled the scores with a downward glancing header. The teams were level at half-time, and after 77 minutes England won a corner. [[Alan Ball Jr.|Alan Ball]] delivered the ball to Geoff Hurst whose deflected shot from the edge of the area found [[Martin Peters]]. He produced the final shot, beating the West German keeper from eight yards to make the score 2–1 to England.{{cite web |first1=Rob |last1=Smyth |first2=Scott |last2=Murray |title=World Cup final 1966: England v West Germany – live! |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2014/may/30/world-cup-final-1966-england-west-germany-live |publisher=theguardian.com (Guardian News and Media) |date=30 May 2014 |accessdate=30 May 2014 }} Germany pressed for an equaliser in the closing moments, and in the 89th minute [[Jack Charlton]] conceded a free kick for climbing on [[Uwe Seeler]] as they both went up for a header. The kick was taken by [[Lothar Emmerich]], who struck it into [[George Cohen]] in the wall; the rebound fell to Held, who shot across the face of goal and into the body of [[Karl-Heinz Schnellinger]]. The ball deflected across the England six-yard box, wrong-footing the England defence and allowing [[Wolfgang Weber]] to level the score at 2–2 and force the match into extra time. Banks protested that the ball had struck Schnellinger on the arm, and reiterated the claim in his 2002 autobiography,{{cite book |last=Banks |first=Gordon |title=Banksy |publisher=Penguin Books |year=2002 |isbn=978-0-7181-4582-8 |page=136 }} but replays showed that it actually struck Schnellinger on the back.{{cite book |last1=Glanville |first1=Brian |title=The Story of the World Cup |publisher=Faber and Faber |location=London |year=2010 |origyear=1973 |isbn=978-0-571-23605-3 |page=154 }} ====Extra time==== [[File:Ghost Goal World Cup 1966.jpg|thumb|Geoff Hurst's "[[Ghost goal|Wembley Goal]]"]] England pressed forward and created several chances. In particular, with five minutes gone, Bobby Charlton struck the post and sent another shot just wide. With 11 minutes of extra time gone, Alan Ball put in a cross and Geoff Hurst swivelled and shot from close range. The ball hit the underside of the crossbar, bounced down and was cleared. The referee Gottfried Dienst was uncertain if it had been a goal and consulted his linesman, [[Tofiq Bahramov]] from Azerbaijan in the USSR, who indicated that it was, and the Swiss referee awarded the goal to the home team. The crowd and the audience of 400 million television viewers were left arguing whether the goal should have been given or not.{{cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=GGgVawPscysC&dat=19660801&printsec=frontpage&hl=en |title=Team Spirit Gains England the cup |date=1 August 1966 |work=Glasgow Herald (Page 4) |accessdate=30 April 2014 }} England's [[Ghost goal#1966 World Cup Final|third goal has remained controversial]] ever since the match. According to the [[Laws of the Game (association football)|Laws of the Game]] the definition of a [[Scoring in association football|goal]] is when "the whole of the ball passes over the goal line".https://www.fifa.com/en/laws/Laws10_01.htm {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070523172940/http://www.fifa.com/en/laws/Laws10_01.htm |date=23 May 2007 }} English supporters cited the good position of the linesman and the statement of Roger Hunt, the nearest England player to the ball, who claimed it was a goal and that was why he wheeled away in celebration rather than attempting to tap the rebounding ball in. Modern studies using film analysis and computer simulation have shown that the ball never crossed the line – both Duncan Gillies of the Visual Information Processing Group at [[Imperial College London]] and Ian Reid and Andrew Zisserman of the Department of Engineering Science at [[University of Oxford]] have stated that the ball would have needed to travel a further 2.5–6.0 cm to fully cross the line.{{Cite journal|last1=Reid |first1=Ian |last2=Zisserman |first2=Andrew |year=1996 |title=Goal-directed Video Metrology |journal=[[European Conference on Computer Vision|Proceedings of the 4th European Conference on Computer Vision]] |volume=II |pages=647–658 |location=New York City |publisher=[[Springer Publishing|Springer]] |editor1-last=Cipolla |editor1-first=R. |editor2-last=Buxton |editor2-first=B. |id=[[LNCS]] 1065 |accessdate=19 May 2012 |url=http://www.robots.ox.ac.uk/~vgg/publications/papers/reid96.pdf |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67mC9unyd?url=http://www.robots.ox.ac.uk/~vgg/publications/papers/reid96.pdf |archivedate=19 May 2012 |deadurl=no |format=PDF }} Some Germans cited possible bias of the Soviet linesman,{{cite web |author=Ken Jones |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football-it-is-possible-to-forget-that-englands-overall-world-cup-record-is-nothing-much-to-shout-about-1286782.html |title=Football: It is possible to forget that England's overall World Cup record is nothing much to shout about |work=[[The Independent]] |date=4 December 1997 |accessdate=21 June 2012}} especially as the USSR had just been defeated in the semi-finals by West Germany.{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/news/67/world-cup/2010/06/26/1996411/two-world-wars-one-world-cup-and-the-achtung-chaos-the |title=Two World Wars, One World Cup And The 'Achtung!' Chaos – The Complex And Violent History Of England Vs Germany |publisher=Goal.com |first=Graham |last=Lister |date=26 June 2010 |accessdate=21 June 2012}} Bahramov later stated in his memoirs that he believed the ball had bounced back not from the crossbar but from the net, and that he was not able to observe the rest of the scene, so it did not matter where the ball hit the ground anyway. One minute before the end of play, the West Germans sent their defenders forward in a desperate attempt to score a last-minute equaliser. Winning the ball, Bobby Moore picked out the unmarked Geoff Hurst with a long pass, which Hurst carried forward while some spectators began streaming onto the field and Hurst scored moments later. Hurst later admitted that his blistering shot was as much intended to send the ball as far into the Wembley stands as possible should it miss, in order to kill time on the clock.{{cite web |url=http://fifaworldcup.yahoo.com/06/en/p/cg/eng_frg_1966.html |title=1966: England – Federal Republic of Germany |accessdate=7 March 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070208113916/http://fifaworldcup.yahoo.com/06/en/p/cg/eng_frg_1966.html |archivedate=8 February 2007}} The final goal gave rise to one of the most famous calls in English football history, when [[BBC]] commentator [[Kenneth Wolstenholme]] described the situation as follows: ''"And here comes Hurst. He's got... [[Pitch invasion|some people are on the pitch]], [[they think it's all over]]. It is now! It's four!"''{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/3020805/Class-of-66-pay-tribute-to-voice-of-football.html |title=Class of '66 pay tribute to voice of football |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=26 March 2002}} One of the balls from the final is on display in the [[National Football Museum]] in [[Manchester]]. ===Details===

West Germany }} |} {| style="width:100%" |- |style="vertical-align:top;width:50%"| {| style="font-size:90%" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" |- !width="25"| !!width="25"| |- |GK ||'''1''' ||[[Gordon footballer)|Ray Wilson]] |- |DM ||'''4''' ||[[Nobby Stiles]] |- |RM ||'''7''' ||[[Alan Ball, Jr.|Alan Ball]] |- |AM ||'''9''' ||[[Bobby Charlton]] |- |LM ||'''16'''||[[Martin Peters]] || {{yel|20}} |- ||[[Horst-Dieter Höttges]] |- |CB ||'''5''' ||[[Willi Schulz]] |- |CB ||'''6''' ||[[Wolfgang Weber]] |- |LB ||'''3''' ||[[Karl-Heinz Schnellinger]] |- |CM ||'''4''' ||[[Franz Beckenbauer]] |- |CM ||'''12'''||[[Wolfgang Overath]] |- |RF ||'''8''' ||[[Helmut Haller]] |- |CF ||'''9''' ||[[Uwe Seeler]] ([[Captain (association football)|c]]) |- |CF ||'''10'''||[[Sigfried Held]] |- |LF ||'''11'''||[[Lothar Emmerich]] |- |colspan=4|'''Manager:''' |- |colspan="4"|[[Helmut Schön]] |} |} {| style="width:100%;font-size:90%" |- |style="width:50%;vertical-align:top"| '''Officials''' * Linesman: [[Tofiq Bahramov]] ([[Football Federation of the Soviet Union|Soviet Union]]) * Linesman: [[Karol Galba|Dr. Karol Galba]] ([[Football Association of the Czech Republic|Czechoslovakia]]) |}
|style="width:50%;vertical-align:top"| '''Match rules''' * 90 minutes * 30 minutes of [[extra time]] if necessary * Replay if scores still level: ** 19:30 BST, Tuesday, 2 August 1966 ** Wembley Stadium, London * No [[Substitute (football)|substitutions]] permitted |} ==Champions photograph and statue== [[File:Champions statue.jpg|thumb|The ''[[World Cup Sculpture]]'' featuring Moore with the World Cup trophy, on the shoulders of [[Geoff Hurst]] and [[Ray Wilson (English footballer)|Ray Wilson]], together with [[Martin Peters]]]] One of the enduring images of the celebrations in Wembley immediately after the game was the picture of the captain [[Bobby Moore]] holding the Jules Rimet Trophy aloft, on the shoulders of Geoff Hurst and Ray Wilson, together with Martin Peters. In recognition of Moore and other [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] players' contribution to the win, the club and Newham Borough Council jointly commissioned a statue of this scene. On 28 April 2003 [[Prince Andrew, Duke of York|Prince Andrew]] as president of [[The Football Association]], duly unveiled the ''[[World Cup Sculpture]]'' (also called ''The Champions'') in a prominent place near West Ham's ground, at the time, the [[Boleyn Ground]], at the junction of [[A124|Barking Road]] and [[Green Street, London|Green Street]]. The {{convert|4|metre|feet|adj=on}}-high bronze piece was sculpted by [[Philip Jackson (sculptor)|Philip Jackson]] and weighed 4 tonnes.{{Cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/2982419.stm |title=World Cup tribute unveiled |publisher=BBC News |date=28 April 2003 |accessdate=5 May 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060203095221/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/2982419.stm |archivedate=3 February 2006}}{{cite news | url=http://www.newham.com/live/attractions/champions_sculpture/33,10,0,0.html | title=Champions Sculpture | work=www.newham.com | accessdate=15 August 2016 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150610214546/http://www.newham.com/live/attractions/champions_sculpture/33,10,0,0.html | archive-date=10 June 2015 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }} ==Cultural impact== [[File:Eng1966 football shirt.jpeg|thumb|Replica of the England shirt worn for the final]] [[File:Close-up of the ball from the 1966 World Cup Final (3302542219).jpg|thumb|Ball used in the final, located in the [[National Football Museum]], Manchester]] The final is the [[List of most-watched television broadcasts#Most watched special events|most watched event ever on British television]], as of July 2018, attracting 32.30 million viewers.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-16671101 "Tracking 30 years of TV's most watched programmes"]. BBC. Retrieved 2 February 2015 In Germany, a goal resulting from a shot bouncing off the crossbar and hitting the line is called a ''Wembley-Tor'' (Wembley Goal) due to the controversial nature of Hurst's second goal. This goal has been parodied a large number of times. Some of the most notable include: * England's third goal was referenced in a 2006 [[Adidas]] advertisement, where English midfielder [[Frank Lampard]] takes a shot at German keeper [[Oliver Kahn]], and a similar event happens. On 27 June 2010 at [[2010 World Cup|that year's World Cup]] a similar goal by Lampard was wrongly disallowed (TV replays showed the ball landing past the goal line before bouncing away) which would have levelled the second-round game against Germany 2–2 (Germany won 4–1). * [[Kenneth Wolstenholme]]'s commentary on the third goal that bounced on the line, "It's a goal!" was used (along with the sound of breaking glass) in the tape-looped coda of an early version of [[The Beatles]] song "[[Glass Onion]]", available on the album ''[[Anthology 3]]''.[http://www.jpgr.co.uk/pcsp729.html Anthology 3 – The Beatles] In August 1966 a [[England Winners stamp|special 4d stamp]] marked ENGLAND WINNERS was issued by the [[Royal Mail]] to celebrate the victory and which soared in value to up to 15 shillings each on the back of public enthusiasm for the victory before falling back in value when the public realised it was not rare. The 1991 [[BBC]] miniseries ''[[Sleepers (TV series)|Sleepers]]'', about a pair of deep-cover [[KGB]] agents placed in England in the mid-1960s and then forgotten includes a subplot about an archive film of the match recorded by Soviet agents and then placed in archives. A KGB officer who sees the film in the early 1990s is excited to discover it includes footage of the disputed goal and attempts to sell it to a contact at a television network (pointedly described as not the BBC). ''Sleepers'' is coy about what the film depicts and in the course of the story, the film is destroyed. Marking the 50th anniversary of England's World Cup victory in July 2016, [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] broadcast ''1966 – A Nation Remembers'', which was narrated by the actor [[Terence Stamp]] who attended every England game at the tournament.{{cite news|title=1966 – A Nation Remembers|url=http://www.itv.com/presscentre/ep1week31/1966-nation-remembers|agency=ITV|date=5 October 2016}} The World Cup win features in the song "[[Three Lions]]" (known by its chorus "Football's Coming Home"), the unofficial anthem of the England football team.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/jul/05/its-coming-home-england-meme-world-cup|title='It's coming home': England are winning the meme World Cup|publisher=The Guardian|date=5 July 2018|accessdate=7 July 2018}} England's win in the final also helped fans to create the "[[Two World Wars and One World Cup]]" chant. ==2009 receipt of winners medals== The players and staff of England's winning squad who did not get medals in 1966 received them on 10 June 2009 after a ceremony at 10 Downing Street in London. Initially, only the 11 players on the pitch at the end of the match received medals, but [[FIFA]] later awarded medals to every non-playing squad and staff member from every [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]]-winning country from [[1930 FIFA World Cup|1930]] to [[1974 FIFA World Cup|1974]].{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/8093891.stm |title=World Cup 1966 winners honoured |date=10 June 2009 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=10 June 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090612032102/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/8093891.stm |archivedate=12 June 2009 |deadurl=no }} ==See also== * [[England–Germany football rivalry]] * [[Ghost goal]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{1966 FIFA World Cup}} {{FIFA World Cup}} {{England national football team matches}} {{Germany national football team matches}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1966 Fifa World Cup Final}} [[Category:FIFA World Cup finals]] [[Category:1966 FIFA World Cup|Final]] [[Category:1966 in London|Fifa World Cup Final, 1966]] [[Category:England national football team matches]] [[Category:Germany national football team matches]] [[Category:Events at Wembley Stadium]] [[Category:West Germany at the 1966 FIFA World Cup|Germany at the 1966 FIFA World Cup]] [[Category:England at the 1966 FIFA World Cup|Final]] [[Category:FIFA World Cup controversies|Final]] [[Category:1966 controversies]] [[Category:England–Germany football rivalry]] [[Category:International association football competitions hosted by London]]

page.title: Anti-Jewish violence in Central and Eastern Europe, 1944–46

revision.text:
The '''anti-Jewish violence in Central and Eastern Europe''' following the retreat of [[Nazi German]] occupational forces and the victorious arrival of the Soviet [[Red Army]] – during the latter stages of World War II – was linked in part to postwar anarchy and economic chaos exacerbated by the [[Stalinism#Stalinist policies|Stalinist policies]] imposed across the territories of expanded [[Soviet republics]] and new satellite countries. The anti-semitic attacks have become frequent in Soviet towns ravaged by war; at the marketplaces, in depleted stores, in schools, and even at state enterprises.<ref name="W-H-S">{{cite book |title=War, Holocaust and Stalinism: A Documented Study of the Jewish Anti-Fascist Committee in the USSR |authors=Shimon Redlich, Kirill Mikhaĭlovich Anderson, I. Alʹtman |publisher=Psychology Press |year=1995 |pages=38–44, 97, 229, 459 |url=https://books.google.com/books?redir_esc=y&id=iO1u1qjs61IC&q=anti-semitic%2Bincidents}}</ref> Protest letters were sent to Moscow from numerous Russian, Ukrainian and Belarusian towns by the [[Jewish Anti-Fascist Committee]] involved in documenting [[the Holocaust]].<ref name="W-H-S"/>
==History== The Soviet authorities failed to address the years of Hitler's anti-Jewish propaganda, wrote Colonel [[David Dragunsky]]; anti-Semitic elements from among the former [[Russian collaborationism with the Axis powers|Nazi collaborators in the Soviet Union]] were often put in charge of state enterprises.<ref name="W-H-S"/> [[Solomon Mikhoels|Solomon Mikhailovich Mikhoels]], Chairman of JAFC murdered in Minsk in January 1948 wrote that Jewish homes were not being returned. In [[Berdichev]], [[Mohyliv-Podilskyi|Mogilev-Podolsk]] [[Balta, Ukraine|Balta]], [[Zhmerinka]], [[Vinnitsa]], [[Khmelnik]], [[Stara Rafalivka|Old Rafalovka]] and many other towns, Jews were forced to remain in the areas of former [[Nazi ghetto]]s for their own safety.<ref name="W-H-S"/> The Jewish Anti-Fascist Committee (JAFC) was targeted by Soviet authorities directly in the so-called [[rootless cosmopolitan]] campaign of the second half of the 1940s and in the [[Night of the Murdered Poets]].<ref name=Medvedev>{{cite book |last=Medvedev |first=Zhores |authorlink=Zhores Medvedev |title=Сталин и еврейская проблема: новый анализ |trans-title=Stalin and the Jewish Question: New Analysis |publisher=Prava Cheloveka |location=Moscow |year=2003 |isbn=5-7712-0251-7 |url=http://scepsis.net/library/id_1473.html |ref=harv |page=148}}</ref><ref name=Pinkus>{{cite book |last=Pinkus |first=Benjamin |title=The Soviet Government and the Jews 1948-1967: A Documented Study |year=1984 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Cambridge |isbn=0-521-24713-6 |pages=183–184 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V7g8AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA183#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
{{quote|The [[Jewish Anti-Fascist Committee|JAFC Presidium]] met in late August, 1944, with a commander of a Jewish partisan unit from Belorussia. Answering a question concerning attitudes of the non-Jewish population towards Jews in [[Minsk]], he stated: "... the attitude wasn't good. There have been numerous anti-semitic incidents ... a battle for apartments has started ... there are difficulties concerning employment.<ref name="W-H-S"/>}}
Several months after the Mikhoels assassination, other Jewish figures were arrested. His death signalled the beginning of the country-wide repressions of the Jews accused of espionage and economic crimes. A campaign against Zionism was launched in the fall of 1948. By the end of the decade Jews disappeared from the upper echelons of the party in the republics.<ref name="ZYGi">{{cite book |work=A Century of Ambivalence: The Jews of Russia and the Soviet Union, 1881 to the Present |author=Zvi Y. Gitelman |publisher=Indiana University Press |year=2001 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=crBhRHqSlJYC&q=Mikhoels+murder |pages=144–154 |title=The Black Years and the Gray, 1948-1967}}</ref> This was followed by the [[Doctors' plot|Jewish doctor-killers case]] of 1952–53 accompanied by publications of anti-Semitic texts in the media,<ref name="Brent-Naumov">{{cite book |last=Brent |first=Jonathan |author2=Vladimir P. Naumov |year=2003 |title=Stalin's Last Crime: The Plot Against the Jewish Doctors, 1948-1953 |publisher=HarperCollins |location=New York |isbn=0-06-019524-X |page=4}}</ref> and hundreds of torture interrogations.<ref name="S-Mo">{{cite book | last=Sebag-Montefiore |first=Simon |authorlink=Simon Sebag-Montefiore |year=2005 |title=Stalin: The Court of the Red Tsar |publisher=Vintage Books |location=New York |isbn=1-4000-7678-1 |page=636}}</ref> Most communities in the Soviet Union never acknowledged the involvement of the local auxiliary police in [[the Holocaust]].<ref name="MM">{{cite journal |author=Meredith M. Meehan |year=2010 |title=Auxiliary Police Units in the Occupied Soviet Union, 1941-43: A Case Study of the Holocaust in Gomel, Belarus |url=https://www.usna.edu/History/_files/documents/Honors-Program/2010/Meehan_Honors_Thesis.pdf |publisher=United States Naval Academy |via=PDF file, direct download 2.13 MB |page=44}}</ref><ref name="AG">{{cite journal|title=Memorial Narratives of WWII Partisans and Genocide in Belarus |author=Alexandra Goujon |publisher=University of Bourgogne |location=France |url=http://ww2-historicalmemory.org.ua/docs/eng/Goujon.doc |via=DOC file, direct download |date=28 August 2008 |page=4 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160805231205/http://ww2-historicalmemory.org.ua/docs/eng/Goujon.doc |archivedate=5 August 2016 |df= }}</ref><ref name="JPHi">{{cite journal|title=Bringing the Dark Past to Light. The Reception of the Holocaust in Postcommunist Europe |authors=John-Paul Himka and Joanna Beata Michlic |page=16 |publisher=University of Nebraska Press |url=http://www.nebraskapress.unl.edu/Supplements/excerpts/Spring%2013/9780803225442_excerpt.pdf |ISBN=0803246471 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151022072804/http://www.nebraskapress.unl.edu/Supplements/excerpts/Spring%2013/9780803225442_excerpt.pdf |archivedate=2015-10-22 }}</ref> The vast majority of the 300,000 ''[[Schutzmannschaft]]'' members in the German-occupied territories of the USSR,<ref name="dean">{{cite book |first=Martin |last=Dean |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tdzTU1Uj3zcC&pg=PA60 |title=Collaboration in the Holocaust: Crimes of the Local Police in Belorussia and Ukraine, 1941-44 |year=2003 |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |isbn=9781403963710 |page=60}}</ref><ref name="ASi-1">{{cite book |title=Bashert: A Granddaughter's Holocaust Quest |author=Andrea Simon |publisher=Univ. Press of Mississippi |year=2002 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u21Wsx6PtMUC&q=%28Schutzmannschaft%29 |ISBN=1578064813 |work=Atonement |page=225}}</ref> quietly returned to their former lives, including members of the [[Byelorussian Home Defence]] participating in the pacification actions in which some 30,000 Jews were murdered,<ref name="Mironowicz">{{cite web|url=http://autary.iig.pl/mironowicz_e/knihi07-26.htm |title=Okupacja niemiecka na Białorusi |publisher=Związek Białoruski w RP, Katedra Kultury Białoruskiej Uniwersytetu w Białymstoku (Internet Archive) |work=Historia Białorusi od połowy XVIII do XX w. [History of Belarus, mid 18th century until the 20th century] |year=2014 |accessdate=12 July 2014 |author=Eugeniusz Mironowicz |trans-title=German occupation of Belarus |language=Polish, Belarusian |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927221149/http://autary.iig.pl/mironowicz_e/knihi07-26.htm |archivedate=September 27, 2007}}</ref> and members of ''[[Ukrainische Hilfspolizei]]'' battalions responsible for the extermination of 150,000 Jews in the area of [[Volhynia]] alone.<ref name="ASt">{{cite book |title=The Soviet Counterinsurgency in the Western Borderlands |author=Alexander Statiev |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2010 |page=69}}</ref> Khrushchev proclaimed that the Jews were not welcome in the Ukraine.<ref name="BPi">{{cite book |title=The Jews of the Soviet Union: The History of a National Minority |author=Benjamin Pinkus |page=219 |work=Anti-Semitism |ISBN=0521389267 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=52Ew77pZsNUC&q=proclaimed+not+welcome}}</ref>
==Satellite countries== {{further|Anti-Jewish violence in Poland, 1944–46}} Upon the Soviet takeover of Poland "only a fraction of [the Jewish] deaths could be attributed to anti-semitism" wrote [[Jan T. Gross]].<ref name="Gross">{{cite book|last=Gross|first=Jan T.|title=Studies in Contemporary Jewry|editor=Jonathan Frankel|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2005|chapter=After Auschwitz: The Reality and Meaning of Postwar Antisemitism in Poland|isbn=0-19-518224-3}}</ref> Most have been caused by the raging [[Anti-communist resistance in Poland (1944–1946)|anti-communist insurrection]] against the new pro-Soviet government.<ref name="SG-1">{{cite web |url=http://www.ceeol.com/aspx/getdocument.aspx?logid=5&id=21F8A4F9-9306-4E36-81FD-7E84C781B737 |title=Central and Eastern European Online Library (CEEOL); page 11, note 7 of current document |publisher=Kwartalnik Historii Żydów, Recenzje (Jewish History Quarterly; Reviews) |work=Book review of Stefan Grajek, "Po wojnie i co dalej? Żydzi w Polsce, w latach 1945−1949", translated from Hebrew by Aleksander Klugman, [[Żydowski Instytut Historyczny]], Warsaw 2003 (p. 95) |author=August Grabski | page=240 |format=PDF |via=direct download, 1.03 MB | language=Polish}}</ref> The [[anti-Jewish violence in Poland, 1944–46]] took the lives of at least 327 Jews.<ref name="Engel">{{cite book |first=David |last=Engel |title=Yad Vashem Studies Vol. XXVI |year=1998 |chapter=Patterns Of Anti-Jewish Violence In Poland, 1944-1946 |chapterurl=http://www1.yadvashem.org/odot_pdf/Microsoft%20Word%20-%203128.pdf |publisher=[[Yad Vashem]] |chapter-format=PDF |page=32}}</ref>
Hundreds of returning Jews were killed in [[Romania]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Minicy Catom Software Engineering Ltd. www.catom.com |url=http://www.jcpa.org/JCPA/Templates/ShowPage.asp?DRIT=3&DBID=1&LNGID=1&TMID=111&FID=624&PID=0&IID=2329&TTL=Manfred_Gerstenfeld_on_The_Jews_Are_Coming_Back:_The_Return_of_the_Jews_to_Their_Countries_of_Origin_after_WWII |title=Institute for Global Jewish Affairs – Global Antisemitism, Anti-Israelism, Jewish Studies |publisher=Jcpa.org |date=1946-07-04 |accessdate=2010-04-08}}</ref><ref>[[Jean Ancel]], "The Return of the Survivors from Transnistria," in David Bankier, ed., The Jews Are Coming Back (Yad Vashem, 2005), 241.</ref> Anti-Jewish manifestations, sometimes based on blood libel accusations, took place in [[Hungary]] in a dozen of places,<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Tdn6FFZklkcC&pg=RA1-PA333&lpg=RA1-PA333&dq=hungary+pogroms&source=web&ots=qJXqqbyIWO&sig=aXHp-luRrNeDV7WWrPEs_5kkO78&hl=pl&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=1&ct=result |title=Antisemitism: a historical ... - Google Książki |publisher=Books.google.pl |date=1939-01-30 |accessdate=2010-04-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polhist.hu/multunk/letoltes/petoa.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721112348/http://www.polhist.hu/multunk/letoltes/petoa.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-07-21 |author=Petö Andrea |title=Népbiróság és vérvád az 1945 utáni Budapesten |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2010-04-08 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0411/is_/ai_76026452 |title=Antisemitism in Post World War II Hungary - violence, riots; Communist Party policy | Judaism | Find Articles at BNET |publisher=Findarticles.com |date= |accessdate=2010-04-08 | first=Peter | last=Kenez | year=2001}}</ref> for example, in [[Kunmadaras pogrom|Kunmadaras]] (two or four dead victims) and [[Miskolc pogrom|Miskolc]].
In [[Slovakia]] in [[Topoľčany pogrom|Topoľčany]] 48 Jews were seriously injured in September 1945. A number of Jews was murdered in [[Kolbasov]] in December. Reportedly 13 anti-Jewish incidents called ''partisan pogroms'' took place 1–5 August 1946, the biggest one in [[Žilina]], where 15 people were wounded.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cs-magazin.com/index.php?a=a2006081058 |title=CS Magazin |publisher=CS Magazin |date= |accessdate=2010-04-08}}</ref> Anti-Semitic manifestations took place in [[Bratislava]] in August 1946 and in August 1948 including anti-Jewish riots in several other locations.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.upn.gov.sk/publikacie_web/pamat-naroda/pamat-naroda-03-2007.pdf |quote=The Jewish demands to return lost property caused and open resistance of a certain part of Slovak community. The frustration was transformed into anti-Jewish riots that took place in Bratislava and several other cities and villages... |at=28 (27 / 100) in PDF |publisher=Studie Pamat Naroda |author=Mgr. Ivica Bumova, PhD |title=Protizidovske vytrznosti v Bratislave v historicksom kontexte}}</ref><ref>[http://www.druhasvetova.sk/2013/06/17/protizidovske-nepokoje-v-bratislave-august-1946-august-1948-v-atmosfere-povojnoveho-antisemitizmu-na-slovensku/ Protizidovske nepokoje v Bratislave - August 1946 - August 1948.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130623045108/http://www.druhasvetova.sk/2013/06/17/protizidovske-nepokoje-v-bratislave-august-1946-august-1948-v-atmosfere-povojnoveho-antisemitizmu-na-slovensku/ |date=2013-06-23 }}</ref>
In [[Kiev]], [[Ukraine]] on September 4–7, 1945,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.quest-cdecjournal.it/focus.php?id=212 |title=State-sponsored Anti-Semitism in Postwar USSR. Studies and Research Perspectives; Antonella Salomoni |publisher=Quest. Issues in Contemporary Jewish History / Questioni di storia ebraica contemporanea |date= |accessdate=2012-07-26}}</ref> around one hundred Jews were beaten, of whom thirty-six were hospitalized and five died of wounds.<ref>Amir Weiner. ''Making Sense of War: The Second World War and the Fate of the Bolshevik Revolution.'' [[Princeton University Press]]. 2008. p. 192.</ref> In [[Rubtsovsk]], Russia a number of anti-Semitic incidents took place in 1945.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iO1u1qjs61IC&pg=RA1-PA228&lpg=RA1-PA228&dq=Rubtsovsk+1945&source=bl&ots=QJpvvo9cbm&sig=NDVN0PgNOOyPYu_Yge35rM2lmRc&hl=pl&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=2&ct=result#PRA1-PA229,M1 |title=War, Holocaust and Stalinism: a ... - Google Książki |publisher=Books.google.pl |date= |accessdate=2010-04-08}}</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{cite book|title=European Jewry Ten Years After the War: An Account of the Development and Present Status of the Decimated Jewish Communities of Europe|author=Nehemiah Robinson|publisher=Institute of Jewish Affairs of the World Jewish Congress|year=1956|page=100|location=New York}} * [http://www.quest-cdecjournal.it/focus.php?id=212 State-sponsored Anti-Semitism in Postwar USSR. Studies and Research Perspectives by Antonella Salomoni]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Anti-Jewish Violence In Eastern Europe, 1944-1946}} [[Category:1940s in Europe]] [[Category:Aftermath of World War II]] [[Category:Anti-Jewish violence in Central and Eastern Europe, 1944–46]] [[Category:Antisemitism in Poland]] [[Category:Antisemitism in Ukraine]] [[Category:Antisemitism in Russia]] [[Category:Antisemitism in Slovakia]] [[Category:Antisemitism in Hungary]] [[Category:Antisemitism in Romania]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Budapest Opera interior.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Budapest State Opera, interior]] The '''Budapest Opera Ball''' (''Budapesti Operabál'' in [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]], ''Budapester Opernball'' in [[German language|German]]) is an annual [[Hungary|Hungarian]] [[upper class|society]] event taking place in the building of the [[Budapest Opera]] (''Operaház'') on the last Saturday of the carnival season, usually late February.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.operabal.com/eng/operabal_tortenete.html |title=普通のデリヘルに飽きてしまった方は日本橋ヘルスの扉を叩け！ |accessdate=2014-05-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131106193421/http://www.operabal.com/eng/operabal_tortenete.html |archivedate=2013-11-06 |df= }}</ref> On this occasion the stage and the auditorium of the Opera is transformed into a huge ballroom. The dress code is [[White tie|evening dress]]: white tie and tailcoat for men, floor-length [[gown]]s for women. The ball is opened by more than a hundred [[debutante]] dancers after a show consisting of selected [[aria]]s, followed by the ''Alles [[Waltz|Walzer]]'' with people dancing until dawn. Recent international guests include [[Montserrat Caballé]], [[Ornella Muti]], [[Yevgeny Nesterenko]], [[Walter Berry (bass-baritone)|Walter Berry]], [[Heinz Zednik]], [[Katia Ricciarelli]], [[Patrizio Buanne]], [[Catherine Deneuve]], [[Katarina Witt]], [[Gina Lollobrigida]], [[Daryl Hannah]], and [[Guy de Rothschild]]. Besides such guests as these, the balls are highlighted by the best-known Hungarian [[opera singers]].
The Opera Ball was first organised on March 2, 1886.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jagellobusinesshotel.hu/en/Programmes_in_Budapest/Opera_Ball.html |title=Budapesti Háromcsillagos Szálloda: Jagelló Business Hotel Budapest |accessdate=2010-01-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721110120/http://www.jagellobusinesshotel.hu/en/Programmes_in_Budapest/Opera_Ball.html |archivedate=2011-07-21 |df= }}</ref> Suspended in 1934, it was not revived until 1996. Representing a tradition rooted in [[Austrian-Hungarian]] culture of the 1880s, the [[revival (theatre)|revival]] has become the most prestigious meeting point of the participants of the Hungarian public life, fully covered by national media.
In 2011, a charity Gala Concert was substituted for the Opera Ball with as a gesture "of contribution to the work of the Government, the leading institutions and the citizens" to help those Hungarians afflicted by the ongoing financial crisis and the various natural disasters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://index.hu/kultur/2011/01/06/elmarad_az_operabal/|title=Elmarad az Operabál|publisher=|accessdate=5 July 2017|date=2011-01-06}}</ref>
==See also==
* [[Opernball (disambiguation)]]
<references/> {{Budapest}}

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}}
'''Collaborating Centre for Oxford University and CUHK for Disaster and Medical Humanitarian Response (CCOUC)'''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ccouc.org|title=Collaborating Centre for Oxford University and CUHK for Disaster and Medical Humanitarian Response (CCOUC)|publisher=ccouc.org|access-date=24 June 2016}}</ref> was established jointly by [[Oxford University]] and [[The Chinese University of Hong Kong]] (CUHK) as a non-profit research centre to carry out research, training and community knowledge transfer in the area of disaster and medical humanitarian response in Greater China and the Asia-Pacific Region.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ndm.ox.ac.uk/collaborations-and-ventures|title=Collaborations and Ventures, Nuffield Department of Medicine, Oxford University|publisher=University of Oxford|access-date=24 June 2016}}</ref> It is housed in the [[CUHK Faculty of Medicine]] and its director is [[Emily Ying Yang Chan]] as of 2016.
==History== CCOUC was established jointly by [[Oxford University]] and [[The Chinese University of Hong Kong]] (CUHK) in April 2011. Its founding director is [[Emily Ying Yang Chan]].
==Mission== CCOUC aims to minimise the negative health impact of disasters experienced by vulnerable populations in the region by serving as a platform for research, education, and community knowledge transfer in the areas of disaster and medical humanitarian crisis policy development, planning, and response.
==Focus and activities== CCOUC's main initiatives include the study and promotion of population's disaster preparedness,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/comment/insight-opinion/article/1359390/hongkongers-are-ill-prepared-aftermath-natural-disaster|title=Hongkongers are ill prepared for aftermath of natural disaster|website=South China Morning Post|access-date=27 June 2016}}</ref> disaster preparedness kit,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1464032/hk40-disaster-relief-bag-makes-difference-between-life-or-death|title=HK$40 kit bag that makes difference of life or death|website=South China Morning Post|access-date=27 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1745613/hong-kong-people-not-ready-deal-disaster-experts-say|title=Hong Kong people not ready to deal with natural disasters, experts say|website=South China Morning Post|access-date=27 June 2016}}</ref> bottom-up approach to disaster relief,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/comment/letters/article/1576280/more-lives-saved-bottom-approach-disaster-relief|title=More lives saved with bottom-up approach to disaster relief|website=South China Morning Post|access-date=27 June 2016}}</ref> [[Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://programme.rthk.hk/channel/radio/programme.php?name=radio3/hongkongtoday&d=2015-03-23&p=513&e=296437&m=episode|title=RTHK Radio 3's morning current affairs programme "Hong Kong Today" --Workshop on reducing disaster risks|publisher=RTHK|access-date=27 June 2016}}</ref> climate change and health.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1256703-20160426.htm|title=RTHK Radio 3's main evening newscast "Newswrap" (18:00 – 19:00, 26 April)|publisher=RTHK|access-date=27 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/1938927/young-hongkongers-lagging-old-adapting-green|title=Young Hongkongers lagging the old in adapting to green lifestyle|website=South China Morning Post|access-date=27 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.chinadailyasia.com/hknews/2016-04/26/content_15423076.html|title=Older people better at carbon reduction, study shows|website=China Daily|access-date=27 June 2016}}</ref> CCOUC also runs an Ethnic Minority Health Project in China to study and promote disaster preparedness and public health in remote rural villages in the country's inland western provinces<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-asia-disaster-health-idUSKCN0WH2WC|title=Health experts train local communities to prepare for disasters|agency=Reuters|access-date=27 June 2016}}</ref>
The Centre has participated in the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO)'s consultation meeting on disaster health risk management and established international co-operation with leading institutions in the field, including the [[Centre for Research on the Epidemiology of Disasters]] (CRED)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cred.be/|title=Centre for Research on the Epidemiology of Disasters (CRED)|website=cred.be|access-date=24 June 2016}}</ref> in [[Belgium]], and [[Harvard Humanitarian Initiative]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://hhi.harvard.edu/affiliated-programs |title=Harvard Humanitarian Initiative|website=hhi.harvard.edu/affiliated-programs/|access-date=24 June 2016}}</ref> and [[FXB Center for Health and Human Rights]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://fxb.harvard.edu/|title=FXB Center for Health and Human Rights|website=fxb.harvard.edu|access-date=24 June 2016}}</ref> at [[Harvard University]].
The Secretariat for World Health Organization Thematic Platform for Health Emergency & Disaster Risk Management Research Group (WHO TPRG) has been set up at CCOUC since October 2016. CCOUC has also been recognised by [[Integrated Research on Disaster Risk International (IRDR)|Integrated Research on Disaster Risk International]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.irdrinternational.org/ |title=Integrated Research on Disaster Risk International|publisher=irdrinternational.org|access-date=23 December 2016}}</ref> to lead one of its 12 International Centre of Excellence since November 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Four New ICoEs Joined IRDR Family!|url=http://www.irdrinternational.org/2016/11/30/four-new-icoes-joined-irdr-family/}}</ref> The Centre has also been appointed Sphere Country Focal Point for China since August 2014 to promote the internationally recognised minimum standards in humanitarian response for the Geneva-based International Sphere Project.
==Partners== * [[Auxiliary Medical Service]] (AMS) – Hong Kong * [[Centre for Research on the Epidemiology of Disasters]], Université catholique de Louvain (CRED) – Belgium * [[FXB International|François-Xavier Bagnoud Center for Health and Human Rights]], Harvard University (FXB) – United States * [[Harvard Humanitarian Initiative]], Harvard University (HHI) – United States * [http://www.cuhk.edu.hk/iees/ Institute of Environment, Energy and Sustainability (IEES)], CUHK * Public Health Emergency Center at [[Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention]] (China CDC) – China * [[Public Health England]] (PHE) – United Kingdom * School of Architecture, Planning and Policy Development, [[Bandung Institute of Technology]] (ITB) – Indonesia * [[Sphere Project]] – International * [http://thewgo.org/website/eng/ World Green Organisation] (WGO) – Hong Kong * Yunnan Health and Development Research Association (YHDRA) – China
==See also== * [[Disaster Risk Reduction]] * [[Climate change adaptation]] * [[Emergency Management]] * [[Natural Disasters]] * [[Vulnerability]] * [[Climate Change]] * [[Risk Management]] * [[World Health Organization]] * [[United Nations International Strategy for Disaster Reduction]] * [[University of Oxford|Oxford University]] * [[The Chinese University of Hong Kong]] * [[CUHK Faculty of Medicine]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}

{{ref improve|date=June 2014}} The '''Doomsday Festival''' was a two-day [[music festival]] held August 19-20, [[2000 in music|2000]], at the [[Ostragehege]] in [[Dresden, Germany]]. The event featured a wide range of bands, but is best known as the occasion of [[Skinny Puppy]]'s reunion concert, which closed the festival and was recorded for the live album ''[[Doomsday: Back and Forth Series 5: Live in Dresden]]'' (2001). It was Skinny Puppy's first concert since 1992, first in Europe since 1988, and first ever in the former [[East Germany]]. [[The Sisters of Mercy]] headlined the first day of the festival.
==Concert line-up== ===Day one===
* [[Unheilig]] * [[Illuminate (band)|Illuminate]] * [[Zeromancer]] * [[Letzte Instanz]] * [[De/Vision]] * [[In Extremo]] * [[Phillip Boa|Phillip Boa & The Voodooclub]] * [[Wolfsheim (band)|Wolfsheim]] * [[The Sisters of Mercy]]
===Day two=== * [[Accessory (band)|Accessory]] * [[Philtron (band)|Philtron]] * [[Velvet Acid Christ]] * [[Terminal Choice]] * [[Covenant (band)|Covenant]] * [[And One]] * [[Skinny Puppy]]
==External links==
*[https://web.archive.org/web/20010124162200/http://www.doomsdayfestival.de/ Official site (archived)]
