revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/Patoonator|Patoonator]] ([[User talk:Patoonator|talk]]): Not really notable. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
Added content on ongoing investigation (in Case Review).
revision.text:
{{Location map many | Ireland | width = 250 | caption = Locations associated with the Kerry Babies case | lat1_deg = 51.948 | lon1_deg = -10.224 | label1 = Cahersiveen | lat2_deg = 52.35 | lon2_deg = -9.6833 | label2 = Abbeydorney }} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Use Irish English|date=May 2013}} The '''Kerry Babies''' case was a 1984 investigation by the [[Garda Síochána]] in [[County Kerry]], Ireland, into the killing of one newborn baby and the alleged killing of another. The mother who [[concealing birth|concealed]] the second baby, Joanne Hayes, was arrested and charged with the [[murder]] of the first baby, of which she was erroneously thought to be the mother. The Gardaí were forced to drop the charges four years later and a [[Public inquiries in the Republic of Ireland|tribunal of inquiry]] (the "Kerry Babies Tribunal") was launched. Its report was critical of the Garda conduct of the investigations, and also concluded that Hayes had precipitated the death of her baby. Hayes has disputed this finding, and no charges were pressed. The parents and killer of the first baby have never been identified.
==Events== On 14 April 1984, a newborn baby boy was found dead of 28 stab wounds<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/36814502|title=Cosmic trigger. Volume II, Down to earth|last=1932-2007.|first=Wilson, Robert Anton,|date=1996|publisher=New Falcon Publications|isbn=1561840114|edition=(Rev. 2nd ed.)|location=Scottsdale, AZ, U.S.A.|oclc=36814502}}</ref> on White Strand beach at [[Caherciveen]], [[County Kerry]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kerryman.ie/news/grim-discovery-one-of-three-in-seven-years-829076.html|title=Grim discovery one of three in seven years|publisher=Kerryman.ie|accessdate=6 February 2013}}</ref> A woman, Joanne Hayes from [[Abbeydorney]], approximately 80 kilometres away, was known to have been pregnant, was arrested and she and her family confessed to the murder of the baby. However, they later withdrew their confessions and admitted instead that Hayes' baby had been born on the family farm, had died shortly after birth, and had been wrapped in a plastic bag and buried on the farm in secret. Tests showed that the baby whose body was found on the farm had the same blood type – O – as Hayes and its (married) father, Jeremiah Locke. However, the baby on the beach had blood group A.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kerry babies recap|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/kerry-babies-recap-explained-3799984-Jan2018/|publisher=The Journal|accessdate=17 January 2018}}</ref><ref name="Case">{{Cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/kerry-babies-case-to-be-reviewed-based-on-new-evidence-1.3357151|title=‘Kerry babies’ case to be reviewed based on new evidence|last=Roche|first=Barry|date=16 January 2018|work=Irish Times|access-date=16 January 2018}}</ref> The Gardaí nevertheless insisted that Hayes had become pregnant simultaneously by two different men (through [[heteropaternal superfecundation]]) and had given birth to both children, killing the one found on the beach. Another theory put forward was that the baby's blood type had changed due to decomposition.<ref name="ThisGreatLittleNation">Gene Kerrigan and Pat Brennan (1999). ''This Great Little Nation''. Gill & Macmillan, pp. 177-178. {{ISBN|0-7171-2937-3}}.</ref>
Hayes was charged with murder but the charge was thrown out by a judge, and the Kerry Babies Tribunal, headed by Mr Justice Kevin Lynch, was set up to investigate the behaviour of the Gardaí in the case. Judge Lynch found that Joanne Hayes killed the baby on the farm by choking it to stop it crying, in spite of state [[pathologist]] Dr John Harbison being unable to determine the cause of death.<ref name="ThisGreatLittleNation"/> Judge Lynch rejected claims by the Hayes family that they had been assaulted by Gardaí, or that the [[Confession (law)|confession]]s were obtained through coercion.<ref>https://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/views/kerry-babies-judging-wrongs-of-horror-ordeal-823363.html</ref> Joanne Hayes had claimed that Gardaí slapped, threatened, and coerced her into making a [[false confession]], and other family members had alleged that Gardaí used harassment and physical intimidation to get false confessions.<ref name="Maguire">{{cite journal |url=http://idesweb.bc.edu/isr/system/files/Maguire_ChangingFace.pdf |format=PDF |title= The changing face of Catholic Ireland: Conservatism and liberalism in the Ann Lovett and Kerry Babies scandals |last=Maguire |first=Moira J |journal=Feminist Studies |publisher=University of Maryland |location=College Park |volume=27 |number=2 |date=Summer 2001 |pages=335–358 |accessdate=15 February 2013 |quote=The day after the charges were dropped, the Hayes family lodged complaints against gardai involved in the investigation. Joanne Hayes claimed that gardai slapped, threatened, and coerced her into making a false confession in the murder of the Cahirciveen baby. Others alleged that gardai used harassment and physical intimidation to elicit confessions |doi=10.2307/3178762}}</ref> [[Gene Kerrigan]] commented in 2006, "In the opinion of some, the report never convincingly explained how people who were entirely innocent of any involvement whatever in stabbing a baby should make very detailed confessions that fitted into the facts of the baby found on the beach."<ref name="GK01">{{cite news| url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/a-cruel-new-take-on-kerry-babies-26412517.html | work=Sunday Independent | first=Gene | last=Kerrigan | title=A cruel new take on Kerry babies | date=4 June 2006 |accessdate= 15 February 2013 }}</ref> The case was also noteworthy for having a psychiatrist admit under oath that the definition of ''[[Psychopathy#Sociopathy|sociopath]]'' he had used to describe Joanne Hayes in his testimony would apply to "about half the population of the country".<ref>Inglis 2003 p.179</ref>
==Repercussions== The case raised serious questions about the culture of the [[Garda Síochána]], and the treatment of unmarried mothers in Irish society. Journalist [[Nell McCafferty]]'s book about the case was titled ''A Woman to Blame''. Joanne Hayes co-wrote a book with John Barrett about the episode called ''My Story''. Four gardaí on the case took legal action against the authors and publishers of the book, as well as shops that sold it. They received out-of-court settlements totalling over €127,000.<ref>[http://www.unison.ie/irish_independent/stories.php3?ca=9&si=529554&issue_id=5421 "Detective calls for DNA analysis to settle Kerry Babies case"]. ''[[Sunday Independent (Ireland)|Sunday Independent]]'', 28 November 1999.</ref><ref>[http://archives.tcm.ie/irishexaminer/2005/06/03/story57830747.asp "Senior officer was linked to all tribunals into garda behaviour"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070310230518/http://archives.tcm.ie/irishexaminer/2005/06/03/story57830747.asp |date=10 March 2007 }}. ''[[Irish Examiner]]'', 3 June 2005.</ref>
In the aftermath of the case the murder squad was disbanded, and the four gardaí assigned to desk duties, in what was seen as a demotion. In 2004, Joanne Hayes offered to undergo a [[DNA]] test to establish that she was not the mother of the baby on the beach. However, one of the officers on the case, Gerry O'Carroll, also sought such a test, saying that he believed the tests will prove the superfecundation theory correct.
The parents or killer of the baby on the beach, later named "Baby John", have never been identified. The gravesite has been repeatedly vandalised, but no suspect has ever been identified for this either.<ref name="Gravesite vandalism">{{cite news|title=Fresh hope for solving thirty year old mystery of Kerry Babies|url=http://evoke.ie/news/irish-news/fresh-hope-for-solving-thirty-year-old-mystery-of-kerry-babies|newspaper=Evoke.ie|date=14 December 2015|accessdate=January 20, 2016}}</ref>
== Case Review == A Garda review of the DNA evidence, announced on 16 January 2018, confirmed that Joanne Hayes was not the mother of the infant found at White Strand.<ref name="Case"/> Irish national media reported that Acting [[Garda Commissioner]] Dónall Ó Cualáin offered a full verbal and written apology to Joanne Hayes.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/garda-apologise-to-joanne-hayes-for-stress-and-pain-of-kerry-babies-investigation-36494480.html|title=Gardaí apologise to Joanne Hayes for 'stress and pain' of Kerry Babies investigation|last=O'Sullivan|first=Majella|date=16 January 2018|work=Irish Independent|access-date=16 January 2018}}</ref> This was followed by an apology from the [[Minister for Justice and Equality|Minister for Justice]], [[Charles Flanagan|Charlie Flanagan]] and the [[Taoiseach]], [[Leo Varadkar]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/kerry-babies-taoiseach-tanaiste-and-minister-for-justice-apologise-to-joanne-hayes-823234.html|title=Kerry Babies: Taoiseach apologises to Joanne Hayes and is open to discussing compensation with her|last=O'Cionnaith|first=Fiachra|date=17 January 2018|work=Irish Examiner|access-date=17 January 2018}}</ref>
A new investigation into the circumstances of Baby John's death was also launched.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.ie/irish-news/garda-to-seek-dna-samples-from-locals-in-hunt-for-kerry-baby-killer-36497087.html|title=Gardaí to seek DNA samples from locals in hunt for Kerry baby killer|last=O'Sullivan|first=Majella|date=17 January 2018|work=Irish Independent|access-date=17 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/murder-inquiry-launched-into-death-of-baby-john-in-kerry-in-1984-1.3358121|title=Murder inquiry launched into death of ‘Baby John’ in Kerry in 1984|last=Roche|first=Barry|date=17 January 2018|work=Irish Times|access-date=17 January 2018}}</ref> In September 2018 it was reported that Gardaí were following up on aspects of the original investigation and engaged in house-to-house inquiries on Valentia Island (the island opposite the beach on which Baby John was discovered), as “part of the general investigation”.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/kerry-babies-garda%C3%AD-start-house-to-house-enquiries-on-valentia-1.3639467|title=Kerry Babies: gardaí start house-to-house enquiries on Valentia|last=Lucey|first=Anne|date=24 September 2018|website=Irish Times|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=24 September 2018}}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Crime|Death|Ireland}} *[[List of unsolved deaths]]
==References== ===Sources=== * {{cite book |url=http://opac.oireachtas.ie/AWData/Library3/Library2/DL035878.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=29 November 2013 |date=October 1985 |title=Report |author=Tribunal of Inquiry into the "Kerry Babies" Case |series=Official publications |volume=Pl.3514 |publisher=Stationery Office |location=Dublin}} * {{cite book |last=Hayes |first=Joanne |title=My Story |year=1985 |publisher=Brandon Books |isbn=9780863220807}} * {{cite book |last=Inglis |first=Tom |title=Truth, power and lies: Irish society and the case of the Kerry babies |year=2003 |publisher=University College Dublin Press |isbn=9781904558026}} * {{cite book |last=McCafferty |first=Nell |authorlink=Nell McCafferty |title=A Woman to Blame: The Kerry Babies Case |origyear=1985 |year=2010 |location=Cork |publisher=Attic Press |isbn=9781855942134 }}
===Citations=== {{reflist}}

'''Korean textbook controversy''' refers to controversial content in [[Government of South Korea|government]]-approved [[history]] textbooks used in the [[secondary education]] (high schools) in [[South Korea]]. The controversies primarily concern portrayal of [[North Korea]] and the description of the regime of the South Korean president and dictator [[Park Chung-hee]].
==Historical context== The controversy's origins can be traced at least to 2013, when the South Korea's [[Ministry of Education (South Korea)|Ministry of Education]] instructed publishers to revise their history textbooks.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = South Korea's History Textbook Controversy|url = http://thediplomat.com/2015/04/south-koreas-history-textbook-controversy/|website = The Diplomat|accessdate = 2015-11-24}}</ref> In 2015 the South Korean [[National Institute of Korean History]] announced plans to replace existing history textbooks in high schools with one authorized version by March 2017.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title = A textbook war divides South Korea|url = http://www.latimes.com/opinion/op-ed/la-oe-1022-kirk-south-korea-textbook-controversy-20151022-story.html|website = latimes.com|accessdate = 2015-11-24}}</ref> The state-issued textbooks are to be written by a government-appointed panel of experts.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|title = South Korea accused of rewriting history over schoolbook policy|url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/nov/03/south-korea-accused-rewriting-history-schoolbook-policy|website = the Guardian|accessdate = 2015-11-24|first = Agence|last = France-Presse}}</ref>
In the larger context, this controversy is a part of an ongoing dispute on whether the state should control the content of history textbooks, and possibly enforce a monopoly, or whether individual schools (or teachers) should be free to choose their own textbooks.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Chosun Ilbo "Debates" the Production of History|url = http://sinonk.com/2013/11/10/chosun-ilbo-debates-the-production-of-history/|website = Sino-NK|accessdate = 2015-11-24}}</ref> South Korea used to have a state control over textbooks until the rules were relaxed in 2003 leading to the appearance of several competing textbooks used since, particularly since 2010.<ref name=":2" />
==Criticisms== Existing textbooks have been criticized by the government as well as by the Korean right or conservative side for being too positive on North Korean topics, and for "liberal, left-leaning" bias.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite web|title = Textbook controversy is over competing forms of nationalist history|url = https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2015/11/633_190233.html|website = koreatimes|accessdate = 2015-11-24}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite news|title = South Korea to Issue State History Textbooks, Rejecting Private Publishers|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/13/world/asia/south-korea-to-issue-state-history-textbooks-rejecting-private-publishers.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 2015-10-12|access-date = 2015-11-24|issn = 0362-4331|first = Choe|last = Sang-hun}}</ref> On the other hand, the left, also described as liberals and progressives, represented among others by ''[[The Hankyoreh]]'' newspaper, are critical of the changes such as removing any mentions of the [[Geochang massacre]] and excluding photos of the first [[Inter-Korean summit|North–South summit]], which they have described as biased towards a conservative view of history and the state that lends legitimacy to the pre-democratic, authoritarian, conservative governments.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":3" /> In particular, the regime of Park Chung-hee, the father of the current Korean president, [[Park Geun-hye]], is seen by liberals as given a "white-wash" treatment by the new revisions.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" /><ref>{{Cite news|title = South Korea set to rewrite history books|url = http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/2/b073fa02-70af-11e5-9b9e-690fdae72044.html#axzz3pfVjfFrq|newspaper = Financial Times|date = 2015-10-12|access-date = 2015-11-24|issn = 0307-1766|first = Simon|last = Mundy}}</ref> The conservatives rebuke that the current textbooks describe Park Chung-hee and his predecessor, [[Rhee Syng-man]], in an excessively negative manner.<ref name=ko2/> Other controversial topics involve the framing of the pro-democratic protests against Park's regime,<ref name=":2" /> or the inclusion of the story of Korean teenage heroine [[Yu Gwan-sun]].<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|title = A high school heroine has South Koreans fighting over history textbooks|url = http://www.latimes.com/world/asia/la-fg-south-korea-textbook-battle-20151105-story.html|website = latimes.com|accessdate = 2015-11-24}}</ref>
Liberals had also criticized the action on the grounds that the government control over textbooks is limiting freedom of speech and spreading propaganda.<ref name=":1" /> As of October 22, 2015, a petition against the new textbook reform had over 50,000 signatures.<ref name=":1" /> The government has also been facing several lawsuits, including one by the current textbook authors who accuse the government of [[Defamation|libel]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=ko2>{{Cite web|title = (News Focus) History textbook controversy evolves into academic, ideological conflict - The Korea Observer|url = http://www.koreaobserver.com/news-focus-history-textbook-controversy-evolves-into-academic-ideological-conflict-55659/|website = The Korea Observer|accessdate = 2015-11-27|language = en-US}}</ref> The plan has been described as controversial, and has led to public protests.<ref name=":2" /> Over 400 Korean history professors have expressed their opposition to the proposal.<ref>{{Cite news|title = South Korea fights old battles with new history textbooks|url = http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/c48c9082-7bd4-11e5-a1fe-567b37f80b64.html#axzz3sOXQ9CeC|newspaper = Financial Times|access-date = 2015-11-24|issn = 0307-1766|first = Simon|last = Mundy}}</ref> Outside Korea, the proposal has been criticized by over 200 professors of [[Korean studies]].<ref name=":5" /> An opinion poll showed the Korean public opinion divided into approximately 50% against the new textbook plan, and 36% in favor.<ref name=":2" />
Several commentators compared this to the [[comfort women]] issue, noting that with the recent government interference into the content of history books, South Korea is losing its moral high ground from which it previously criticized the Japanese government for [[Japanese history textbook controversies|its perceived historical textbook problems]].<ref>{{Cite news|title = South Korea fights old battles with new history textbooks|url = http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/c48c9082-7bd4-11e5-a1fe-567b37f80b64.html|newspaper = Financial Times|access-date = 2015-11-27|issn = 0307-1766|first = Simon|last = Mundy}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = [Reporter's column] S. Korea forfeiting moral high ground in Japan dispute|url = http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_international/653201.html|website = www.hani.co.kr|accessdate = 2015-11-27}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Korean nationalist historiography]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== *{{cite book |title=History Textbooks and the Wars in Asia: Divided Memories |volume=31 |series=Routledge Contemporary Asia Series |editor-first1=Gi-Wook |editor-last1=Shin |editor-first2=Daniel C. |editor-last2=Sneider |publisher=Routledge |year=2011 |isbn=113683091X |url=https://books.google.co.jp/books?id=8_-rAgAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=editions:XHgvpL2pFeMC&hl=en}} *{{cite web |title=Divided Memories: History Textbooks and the Wars in Asia |first=Daniel |last=Sneider |date=May 29, 2012 |publisher=Nippon.com |url=http://www.nippon.com/en/in-depth/a00703/}}

The '''Kpalikpakpa zã''' or Kpalikpakpa festival is an annual festival celebrated by the chiefs and people of the [[Kpalime Traditional Area]] located in the [[Volta Region]] of [[Ghana]]. The name of the festival is derived from an appellation in [[Ewe language|Ewe]] which is "''Kpalikpakpa si tu makpata''" which means "shooting without recording". The festival is meant to remind the Kpalime people of the valour of their ancestors during wars in the ancient days.<ref name=first>{{cite news |url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/artikel.php?ID=2839 |title=Kpalime Celebrate Kpalikpakpa Festival |accessdate=2011-09-17 |date=1997-11-05 |publisher=Ghana Home Page}}</ref>
The festival was first held in November 1997 and has been held every year since then. The paramount chief of the area at the time was Togbe Agbi Yao VII. The first festival was at [[Wegbe Kpalime]]. It has been rotated between the towns in the district since then.<ref name=first/> The eighth celebration was hosted at [[Kpale Kpalime|Kpale]] in November 2004.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/economy/artikel.php?ID=67513 |title=Chiefs and people of Kpalime launch festival |accessdate=2011-09-17 |date=2004-10-11 |publisher=Ghana Home Page}}</ref> The 17th edition of the festival was celebrated in November 2012 at Kaira.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kaira Hosts 17th Annual KPALIKPAKPA ZÃ (Festival)|url=http://www.kpalimegh.netii.net/index.php?news&nid=1_17TH-ANNUAL-KPALIKPAKPA-Z-FESTIVAL|publisher=Kpalimegh.netii.net|accessdate=30 January 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External source== *[http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/artikel.php?ID=2839 Ghana Home Page]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kpalikpakpaza}} [[Category:Religious festivals in Ghana]] [[Category:Festivals in Ghana]] [[Category:November events]]

revision.comment: /* top */Fix deprecated image syntax in infobox or other minor fixes using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox military conflict |conflict=La Paz incident |partof=the [[American Civil War]] | image= La Paz, Arizona.jpg | image_size = 300 |caption=''La Paz, circa 1890, already a ghost town.'' |date=May 20, 1863 |place=[[La Paz, Arizona]] |coordinates= |result=Two [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] soldiers killed |combatant1={{flag|United States|1861}} |combatant2={{flag|Confederate States|1863}} |commander1={{flagicon|United States|1861}} [[James A. Hale]] |commander2={{flagicon|Confederate States|1863}} William Edwards |strength1= |strength2= |casualties1=2 killed |casualties2=none |notes=
*''One civilian was wounded by gunfire.'' *''Willam 'Frog' Edwards died in the desert after the shooting while trying to escape the Union Army.'' }} {{Campaignbox Battles of the California Column}} {{Campaignbox Battles in Confederate Arizona}} The '''La Paz incident''' occurred on May 20, 1863 at the mining town of [[La Paz, Arizona|La Paz]], [[Arizona]], and was the westernmost armed confrontation of the [[American Civil War]]. William "Frog" Edwards, only recently released from detention at [[Fort Yuma]], ambushed a party of unarmed Union soldiers when they stopped at La Paz to purchase supplies. Edwards' attack killed one soldier instantly and left another mortally wounded. Edwards then fled into the desert where he died of exposure and dehydration.Masich, pg. 115 ==Incident== After the Confederates established their own Arizona Territory at [[Mesilla, New Mexico]], in February 1862, the Union sent the [[California Column]] east to reinforce the [[Union Army]] engaged in the [[New Mexico Campaign]]. Confederate cavalry briefly occupied Tucson from February 28 until early May 1862, but withdrew soon after the skirmmish at [[Picacho Peak]]. The following year [[General]] [[James H. Carleton]] arrested several California secessionists bound for Texas and detained them at [[Fort Yuma]]; William "Frog" Edwards was one of these detainees. La Paz was one of a handful of mining settlements that had been established along the [[Colorado River]]. It was situated along an important army supply route that had been in use since the [[Yuma War]]. The army used the Colorado River to supply garrisons in Arizona. On the evening of May 20, 1863, the Colorado River steamer ''Cocopah'' arrived at La Paz en route to [[Fort Mohave, Arizona|Fort Mohave]]. A small party of soldiers, under the command of Lieutenant James A. Hale of the [[4th California Infantry]], disembarked to purchase supplies at Cohn's Store.Masich, pg. 115 Lurking in the shadows was William "Frog" Edwards, only recently released from jail at Fort Yuma. As the soldiers approached the store, Edwards opened fire with his revolver. Private Ferdinand Behn was killed instantly, Private Truston Wentworth was mortally wounded and died the following day, Private Thomas Gainor was severely wounded, but recovered. One bystander was also struck and suffered a serious wound. Lieutenant Hale immediately searched the town with his remaining men but did not find Edwards. Lieutenant Hale returned to Fort Yuma aboard the ''Cocopah'' with his dead and wounded the following day. In response to Edwards' attack, a troop of forty men was deployed to hunt him down. Edwards was found several days later in the desert, where he apparently died of exposure and dehydration.Masich, pg. 115 ==See also== *[[St. Albans Raid]] *[[Stanwix Station]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *{{cite book |last=Masich |first= Andrew E.|authorlink= |coauthors= |edition= |title=Civil War in Arizona: the story of the California Volunteers, 1861–1865 |year=2006 |publisher=University of Oklahoma Press |location=Tulsa, Oklahoma |isbn=0-8061-3900-5}} [[Category:Arizona folklore]] [[Category:Military operations of the American Civil War in Arizona]] [[Category:Colorado River]] [[Category:Combat incidents]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Arizona]] [[Category:History of La Paz County, Arizona]] [[Category:History of the American West]] [[Category:1863 in Arizona Territory]] [[Category:May 1863 events]]

{{Unreferenced|date=August 2017}} A '''latent human error''' is a [[human error]] which is likely to be made due to systems or routines that are formed in such a way that humans are disposed to making these errors. Latent human error is a term used in safety work and accident prevention, especially in [[aviation]].
By gathering data about errors made, then collating, grouping and analyzing them, it can be determined whether a disproportionate amount of similar errors are being made. If this is the case, a contributing factor may be disharmony between the respective systems/routines and human nature or [[Propensity probability|propensities]]. The routines or systems can then be analyzed, potential problems identified, and amendments made if necessary, in order to prevent future errors, incidents or accidents.
== See also == *[[Air safety]] *[[Error]]
==Further reading== * James Reason: ''Human Error'', Cambridge University Press; 1st edition (October 26, 1990) {{ISBN|978-0-521-31419-0}}
==External links== * Erik Hollnagel, [http://www.ida.liu.se/~eriho/HumanError_M.htm "The Elusiveness of "Human Error""], 2005 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20030712194750/http://bmj.com/cgi/reprint/320/7237/768.pdf ''Human error: models and management'' – James Reason] British Medical Journal 2000;'''320''':768–70 (Internet Archive) * [http://www.hse.gov.uk/humanfactors/topics/core2.pdf Human factors view of accident causation]
[[Category:Safety engineering]] [[Category:Error]] [[Category:Accidents]]
{{psych-stub}}

page.title: List of games with concealed rules

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2013}} '''Games with concealed rules''' are [[game]]s where the [[Game#Rules|rules]] are intentionally concealed from new players, either because their discovery is part of the game itself, or because the game is a hoax and the rules do not exist. In fiction, the counterpart of the first category are games that supposedly do have a rule set, but that rule set is not disclosed.
==Actual games==
===Discovery games=== * [[Eleusis (card game)|Eleusis]]: A card game in which one player secretly decides on a rule which determines which cards may be played on top of each other. The other players then use deductive logic to work out the secret rule. * [[Haggle (game)|Haggle]]: A party game in which the [[Gamemaster]] divides a set of cards and a subset of the full rules among players and allows them to trade for other cards and rules. * [[Mao (card game)|Mao]]: A [[Shedding-type game|shedding-type]] card game where the winner of a round adds a concealed rule of their choice to all subsequent rounds. * [[Paranoia (role-playing game)|Paranoia]]: A [[tabletop role-playing game]] in which the rules are considered "classified". Only the [[Gamemaster]] has full knowledge of the rules, while other players must deduce them by trial and error as they proceed through the game. (The game acknowledges that players may read the gamemaster section, but ''demonstrating'' knowledge of the rules is considered treasonous, and the gamemaster may also make arbitrary changes.) *[[Penultima]]: A chess variant in which the spectators make secret rules governing how the pieces move and capture. The two players are unaware of the rules and must discover them by inductive reasoning.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Fryers |first1=Michael |year=1998 |title=Penultima |journal=[[Variant Chess]] |volume=3 |issue=28 |pages=164–166}}</ref> * [[Scissors (game)|Scissors]]: A party game in which a pair of scissors is passed between players, with the passer declaring that they are being passed "open" or "closed" based on an individual and secret rule. The other players must use observation to deduce the rule each player uses to make the declaration.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/326383402.html?dids=326383402:326383402&FMT=ABS&FMTS=CITE:AI&type=historic&date=Oct+15%2C+1899&author=&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=TWO+JOLLY+GAMES%2C |title= Two Jolly Games, A Noisy Play Imported From Peru and 'The Spider And The Fly' |date= October 15, 1899 |work= Los Angeles Times |accessdate=March 24, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last= Hofmann |first= Mary Christina |title= Games for Everybody |publisher= Dodge Publishing |location= New York |year= 1905 |url= https://archive.org/stream/games10/games10.txt}}</ref> * Whose Triangle Is It?: A party game in which one player points to three people or objects, forming an imaginary triangle, and then asks "Whose triangle is it?" The triangle belongs to the person closest to the closest object of a similar color to the color of second point of the triangle, but this rule is not told to new players, and the game is for new players to figure out what the rule is.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.yarps.org/resources/games/mind-games/ |title= Mind Games |work= Yarps}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author= Outbound Training |url= http://www.slideshare.net/outboundtraining/team-building-games-outbound-training |title= Team Building Games & Activities |publisher= Slide Share}}</ref> * [[Zendo (game)|Zendo]]: A game in which one player creates a rule for structures to follow and the other players try to discover the rule by building structures * [[Snaps (game)]]: A game in which a player spells out a name using finger snapping and verbal cues. Featured in [[P.S. I Love You (film)]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Snaps|title=How to Play Snaps.|publisher=WikiHow}}</ref>
===Hoax or joke games=== * [[52 Pickup]]: A card game in which dealer scatters the cards on the floor and non-dealer must pick them up. * [[Mornington Crescent (game)|Mornington Crescent]]: Originally a round in the [[BBC Radio 4]] comedy panel game ''[[I'm Sorry I Haven't A Clue]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/comedy/clue/article/|publisher= BBC |title= I'm Sorry I Haven't a Clue: A History |accessdate= July 31, 2007}}</ref> The game consists of each panelist in turn announcing a landmark or street, most often a tube station on the London Underground system. The apparent aim is to be the first to announce "Mornington Crescent", a station on the Northern Line. Despite appearances, however, there are no rules to the game, and both the naming of stations and the specification of "rules" are based on stream-of-consciousness association and improvisation. Thus the game is intentionally incomprehensible.
==Games in works of fiction==
===Games with undisclosed rules=== * [[43-Man Squamish]]: ''MAD Magazine'' published an article outlining a college sport designed to be unplayable. The sport features a pentagonal field, silly-sounding terms and a dummy on each team. * [[Calvinball]]: In the comic series ''[[Calvin & Hobbes]]'', ''Calvinball'' is a game regularly played by the main characters. The only consistent rule of ''Calvinball'' is that "Calvinball may never be played with the same rules twice". * [[Double Fanucci]]: Featured in the computer game [[Zork Zero]], ''Double Fanucci'' has mind-bogglingly complex "rules". Legal play can depend on things like the phase of the Moon and the ancestry of the players. * [[Dragon Poker]]: A fictional card game by [[Robert Asprin]] in the [[MythAdventures]] series. The rules change depending on weather, seating position, time of day, and other undisclosed modifiers. However, a playable version has been created by fans, based on the rules and play that are presented in the books.
===Hoax games=== * [[That Mitchell and Webb Look#Recurring sketches|Numberwang]]: A recurring "game show" on the sketch series ''[[That Mitchell and Webb Look#Recurring sketches|That Mitchell and Webb Look]]''.<ref name="BBC - Numberwang">{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/comedy/thatmitchellandwebbsite/characters/numberwang.shtml |title=BBC - Comedy - That Mitchell And Webb Site - Numberwang |publisher=BBC |accessdate=2012-04-26}}</ref> Similar to ''Mornington Crescent'' above, the "contestants" call out random numbers in an attempt to score a "Numberwang", though the responses are scripted and there are no actual rules to winning a "Numberwang". * Clique: The online satirical gaming magazine ''Critical Miss'' featured rules for a card game called Clique, a parody of collectible card games that used printed cards and spurious spoken rules to confuse onlookers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.criticalmiss.com/issue9/clique1.html|title=Clique: The Uncollectable, Unplayable Card Game|accessdate=September 5, 2007}}</ref> * [[List of games in Star Trek#Fizzbin|Fizzbin]]: In the ''[[Star Trek: The Original Series|Star Trek]]'' episode "A Piece of the Action", [[James T. Kirk]] created this game while he and [[Spock (Star Trek)|Cmdr. Spock]] were being held prisoner. They "taught" the game to the guards, improvising the rules until their captors were sufficiently distracted, then overpowered them and escaped.
==See also== * [[List of fictional games]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Calvinball Calvinball - Television Tropes & Idioms]
[[Category:Fictional games| List of games with concealed rules]] [[Category:Hoaxes|Games with concealed rules]] [[Category:Lists of games|Rules, concealed]] [[Category:Games with concealed rules| List of games with concealed rules]]

{{condense|date=September 2013}} '''Live Earth Alert''' has been organised in the [[Netherlands]] on 7 July 2007 in addition to the worldwide event of [[Live Earth]] and had a unique character because of its length and total concept. ==Background== In the Netherlands they{{who|date=September 2013}} presented and broadcast live a 24hour program 'Live Earth Alert' on 7 July 2007, the day of [[Live Earth]] from almost 08:00-08:00hrs{{clarify|date=September 2013}} including live-streams from all 7 continents and stadiums (in sequential other).
All times in W.E.T., it started early Saturday-morning 07/07 and finished Sunday-morning 07/08. ==Broadcast== [[Nederland 3]] (public television station TV Netherlands 3) by [[BNN (Dutch broadcaster)|BNN]], [[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting|NOS]], [[LLink]] and [[3FM]] (public radio station Radio 3FM) [http://www.bnn.nl/page/pers/46798/LIVE%20EARTH%20OP%20NEDERLAND%203%20EN%203FM BNN: Live Earth on Nederland 3 (TV) and Radio 3FM] ==Concept== Live Earth Alert has included worldwide reports from Dutch correspondents stationed in all 7 seven continents and also from the home-location [[Westerpark]] in [[Amsterdam]]: (Live Earth Alert),[http://www.liveearthalert.nl Live Earth Alert.nl] where parallel run{{clarify|date=September 2013}} a concert-program on stage produced by the Dutch from 12:00-23:00hrs, local time in the Netherlands. ==See also== * [[Live Earth]] * [[21World]] ==References== {{reflist| 2}} ==External links== * [http://www.bnn.nl/page/pers/46798/LIVE%20EARTH%20OP%20NEDERLAND%203%20EN%203FM BNN: Live Earth on Nederland 3 (TV) and Radio 3FM], (in {{nl}}, partly in English) * [http://www.liveearthalert.nl Live Earth Alert.nl] ({{nl icon}}, partly in English) {{Live Earth concerts}} [[Category:Live Earth|2007]] [[Category:2007 in music]] [[Category:Rock festivals in the Netherlands]] [[Category:2007 in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Music festivals established in 2007]] {{music-event-stub}}

[[File:Livret A.png|thumb|Cover of an old Livret A.]]
The '''Livret A''' is a historic financial product offered by [[List of banks in France|French banks]]. Established in 1818 by King [[Louis XVIII of France|Louis XVIII]] to pay back the debts incurred during the [[Napoleonic Wars]], part of the funds are now transferred to and re-invested by the [[Caisse des dépôts et consignations]], owned by the French state, to build [[HLM]], or social housing, and pay back the [[Eurozone debt crisis|Eurozone debt]]. The remaining funds are used by banks to give loans to French [[small and medium-sized enterprises]]. The product acts as a [[savings account]] for French citizens and residents, and the annual returns are not taxed. In 2012, it was owned by 60 million individuals, for a total amount of 220,8 billion Euros.
==Early history== The Livret A was established in 1818 by King [[Louis XVIII of France|Louis XVIII]] to pay back the debts incurred during the [[Napoleonic Wars]].<ref name="latribunemathias">Mathias Thépot, [http://www.latribune.fr/entreprises-finance/banques-finance/industrie-financiere/20120222trib000684383/ou-va-vraiment-l-argent-du-livret-a-.html Où va vraiment l'argent du Livret A ?], ''[[La Tribune]]'', February 22, 2012</ref><ref name="lepointmarc">Marc Vignaud, [http://www.lepoint.fr/actualites-economie/2008-10-01/comprendre-comment-le-livret-a-finance-le-logement-social/916/0/278581 COMPRENDRE - Comment le livret A finance le logement social], ''[[Le Point]]'', October 1, 2008</ref> The funds are held and re-invested through the [[Caisse des dépôts et consignations]], founded in 1816.<ref name="latribunemathias"/>
In the 19th century, the funds were used to build railroad tracks and canals throughout France.<ref name="lepointmarc"/> Between World War I and World War II, it was used to install electricity in rural France.<ref name="latribunemathias"/>
Since 1945, it has mostly been used to build social housing.<ref name="latribunemathias"/>
==Investments== Part of the funds are invested through the Caisse des dépôts et consignations, which is fully owned by the French state.<ref name="latribunemathias"/> In 2011, a decree issued by the Prime Minister suggested that French banks had to transfer 60% of all funds from the Livrets A to the Caisse des dépôts.<ref name="latribunemathias"/> Prior to the decree, [[La Banque Postale]] was the only bank to transfer 100% of all funds from the Livret A to the Caisse des dépôts, while the [[Groupe Caisse d'Épargne]] transferred 80%.<ref name="latribunemathias"/> Commercial banks like the [[Société Générale]] or the [[Crédit Agricole]] only transferred between 20% and 30%.<ref name="latribunemathias"/> All French banks have by 2022 to transfer 60% to the Caisse des dépôts.
Through the Caisse des dépôts, the funds are mostly used to build new social housing known as [[HLM]].<ref name="latribunemathias"/> They are also used to pay back the [[Eurozone debt crisis|Eurozone debt]].<ref name="latribunemathias"/> They are also used to strengthen the collateral of French banks, and to give loans to French [[small and medium-sized enterprises]] and territorial entities (like towns, [[Departments of France|departments]], etc.).<ref name="latribunemathias"/> Finally, the funds are invested in [[Bond credit rating|AAA and BBB-rated]] stocks and Treasury bonds.<ref name="latribunemathias"/><ref name="lepointmarc"/>
The remaining funds are used by banks to give loans to French [[small and medium-sized enterprises]].<ref name="latribunemathias"/>
==Recent years== The product was only offered by [[La Banque Postale]] and the [[Groupe Caisse d'Épargne]] as of 2008.<ref name="lepointmarc"/> Since January 2009, it has been offered by all French banks.<ref name="lepointmarc"/>
As of 2015, only one account may be held by an individual, with an amount from 10 Euros to 22,950 Euros.<ref name="servicepublic">[http://vosdroits.service-public.fr/particuliers/F2365.xhtml Service Public: Épargne : livret A]</ref> During the [[French presidential election, 2012]], [[François Hollande]], who was elected as the President of France, announced his intention to raise the individual amount to 30,600 Euros to build 150,000 new [[HLM]]s.<ref name="latribunemathias"/><ref name="challenges">[http://www.challenges.fr/economie/20120716.CHA9056/les-hlm-rappellent-a-l-ordre-hollande-sur-le-doublement-du-plafond-dulivret-a.html Les HLM rappellent à l'ordre Hollande sur le doublement du plafond duLivret A], ''[[Challenges (magazine)|Challenges]]'', July 16, 2012</ref>
In 2008, 46 million French citizens or residents owned a Livret A, for a total amount of 128,1 billion Euros in late 2007.<ref name="lepointmarc"/> As of January 2012, 60 million owned one, for a total amount of 220,8 billion Euros.<ref name="latribunemathias"/>
The annual [[rate of return]] went down slightly in recent years. In 2010, it has an annual rate of return of 4%. In January 2012, it had an annual [[rate of return]] of 2,25%.<ref name="latribunemathias"/> By 2015, it had fallen to 1%.<ref name="servicepublic"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Banking in France]] [[Category:1818 establishments in France]] [[Category:Aftermath of the Napoleonic Wars]]

[[File:Low Carbon Vehicle Event 2013 Internal Exhibition.jpg|right|thumb| The Low Carbon Vehicle Event 2013 Internal Exhibition]] The '''Low Carbon Vehicle Event''' (LCV), is [[United Kingdom]]'s premier low carbon vehicle event. It is held annually since 2008 at Millbrook Proving Ground at the beginning of September.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/7694094.stm|title=Showcase for green car technology|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=2008-10-28}}</ref> The show consists of a technological exhibition, seminars sessions and Ride & Drive (of latest research and development and commercial available low emission vehicles) activities.<ref>{{cite web|title=LCV 2013 Show Guide |url=http://www.cenex-lcv.co.uk/assets/downloads/lcv2013-show-guide.pdf |accessdate=4 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004215748/http://www.cenex-lcv.co.uk/assets/downloads/lcv2013-show-guide.pdf |archivedate=4 October 2013 |df= }}</ref> LCV is a [[business-to-business]] free-to-attend event organised by [[Cenex]] and whose main aim is promoting the UK supply chain of the low carbon vehicle industry.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cenex Low Carbon Vehicle Event 4/5 September 2013: seminar programme and other latest news|url=http://www.green-car-guide.com/cenex-low-carbon-vehicle-event-45-september-2013-seminar-programme-and-other-latest-news-.html|accessdate=4 October 2013}}</ref>
==LCV history==
The Low Carbon Vehicle Event has been organised annually from 2008 by [[Cenex]] and supporting partners include: [[Department for Business, Innovation and Skills|The Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/department-for-business-energy-and-industrial-strategy|title=Department for Business, Energy & Industrial Strategy - GOV.UK|website=www.gov.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-03-03}}</ref> The Centre for Connected and Autonomous Vehicles, The Office for Low Emission Vehicles,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/office-for-low-emission-vehicles|title=Office for Low Emission Vehicles - GOV.UK|website=www.gov.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-03-03}}</ref> [[Department for International Trade|The Department for International Trade]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/department-for-international-trade|title=Department for International Trade - GOV.UK|website=www.gov.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-03-03}}</ref> The Advanced Propulsion Centre,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.apcuk.co.uk/|title=Advanced Propulsion Centre|website=Advanced Propulsion Centre|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-03-03}}</ref> [[Automotive Council UK|The Automotive Council UK]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.automotivecouncil.co.uk/|title=Automotive Council UK|website=www.automotivecouncil.co.uk|access-date=2017-03-03}}</ref> [[Innovate UK]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/innovate-uk|title=Innovate UK - GOV.UK|website=www.gov.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-03-03}}</ref> [[The Low Carbon Vehicle Partnership]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lowcvp.org.uk/|title=Low Carbon Vehicle Partnership {{!}} Biofuels, Electric Cars & Hydrogen Fuel Cells|website=www.lowcvp.org.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-03-03}}</ref> [[Millbrook Proving Ground|Millbrook]], [[Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders|The Society of Motor Manufacturers]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.smmt.co.uk/|title=SMMT {{!}} Supporting & promoting the UK automotive industry|website=SMMT|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-03}}</ref> and Transport Systems Catapult.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ts.catapult.org.uk/|title=Transport Systems - Catapult|website=Catapult|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-03-03}}</ref>
==LCV 2016==
Cenex prides itself on ensuring the decision makers of the UK industry attend the event with all major stakeholders, key manufacturers, supply chain representatives and government officials from the UK present. The event attracts a range of customers (Automotive 53%, Energy & Infrastructure 8%, Government & Local Authority 7%, Academia 8%) and senior managers including those at board level [38%] and middle management [27%].
LCV2016 set a new record attendance with 3,137 visitors, 226 exhibitors and 1180 organisations represented. This year’s event takes place on Wednesday 6th and Thursday 7thSeptember 2017 at Millbrook and is set to be the biggest and best year yet.
Cenex-LCV is the place to meet UK decision makers and industry experts; the perfect opportunity to showcase your business, your industry and your technology.

'''Madge Augustine Oberholtzer''' (November 10, 1896 – April 14, 1925) was an American woman whose rape and murder played a critical role in the demise of the second incarnation of the [[Ku Klux Klan]]. In March 1925, while working for the state of [[Indiana]] on an adult literacy campaign, she was kidnapped by [[D. C. Stephenson]], [[Grand Dragon]] of the [[Indiana Klan]]. Holding her captive in his private train car, he raped and tortured her. She died from a combination of a [[staphylococcal infection]] from her injuries and [[renal failure|kidney failure]] from [[mercury chloride]] poisoning, which she took while held captive in an attempt to commit suicide.<ref name="Linder">[http://law2.umkc.edu/faculty/projects/ftrials/stephenson/atatevstprosecution.html Daniel O. Linder, "D.C. Stephenson"], Testimony, ''Famous Trials'', hosted at University of Missouri Law School, Kansas City</ref>
Following the suicide attempt, Stephenson's men returned Oberholtzer to her home, assuming her injuries would soon prove fatal and believing their influential leader was immune to any prosecution. However, his victim regained consciousness long enough to give a signed statement to police.<ref>[http://law2.umkc.edu/faculty/projects/ftrials/stephenson/dyingdeclaration.html Dying Declaration of Madge Oberholtzer<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> She described Stephenson's assaults which led to his conviction at trial and led to the rapid decline of KKK membership in Indiana.
==Early life== Born to [[German Americans|German-American]] parents, Oberholtzer grew up in [[Indianapolis]],<ref name=madgedeath /> where her father worked as a postal clerk and her family belonged to the Irvington Methodist Church.<ref name=madgedeath /> She studied English, mathematics, zoology and logic at [[Butler University|Butler College]] in [[Irvington Historic District (Indianapolis, Indiana)|Irvington]], but dropped out at the end of her junior year without saying why.<ref name=madgedeath /> Through her life, Oberholtzer lived with her parents in the Irvington area of Indianapolis.<ref name=madgedeath /> By the time she met Stephenson, she was the manager of the Indiana Young People's Reading Circle, a special section of the Indiana Department of Public Instruction.<ref name=madgedeath /> However, she heard rumors that her job and the Reading Circle program were about to be eliminated due to budget cuts.<ref name=madgedeath />
==Chronology of the murder== Oberholtzer met her murderer while attending Indiana Governor [[Edward L. Jackson]]'s inauguration party at the Athletic Club<ref name=made5232>[http://law2.umkc.edu/faculty/projects/ftrials/stephenson/dyingdeclaration.html The Dying Declaration Of Madge Oberholtzer: The Key Evidence In The 1925 Trial Of D. C. Stephenson, From ''My Indiana'' by Irving Liebowitz (1964) (pp.195-203)]</ref> on January 12, 1925.<ref name=madgedeath /> In her dying statement, Oberholtzer said Stephenson asked her for a date several times after the banquet, but she refused.<ref name=made5232 /> However, she eventually agreed and they had dinner together.<ref name=madgedeath /> Following that date, Stephenson called Oberholtzer on the phone several times. She finally agreed to meet him for dinner at the [[Hotel Washington (Indianapolis, Indiana)|Washington Hotel]] in Indianapolis.<ref name=made5232 />
They began seeing each other more frequently,<ref name=madgedeath /> and she acted as his aide during the 1925 session of the [[Indiana General Assembly]],<ref name=madgedeath /> carrying messages from his office to his friends.<ref name=madgedeath /> She also helped him write a nutrition book, "One Hundred Years of Health".<ref name=madgedeath /> Using her Reading Circle connections, she intended to help him sell the book to school libraries throughout the state.<ref name=madgedeath /> However, she ended her relationship with him after attending a party at his mansion. They would not meet again until Sunday, March 15.<ref name=made5232 />
About 10:00 p.m. that day, Oberholtzer returned home after an evening with a friend.<ref name=madgedeath /> Her mother told her that Stephenson's secretary had called<ref name=madgedeath /> and said he was leaving for Chicago. He wanted her to call him before he left.<ref name=made5232 /> She called Stephenson, and he told her he would try to protect the Reading Circle program and her job if she agreed to see him.<ref name=made5232 /> She changed into a black velvet dress,<ref name=madgedeath /> and a bodyguard she named as "Mr Gentry" arrived and escorted her to Stephenson's mansion a few blocks away.<ref name=made5232 /><ref name=made5232 /> When she arrived, Stephenson, his chauffeur,<ref name=made5232 /> Gentry, and another bodyguard Oberholtzer named as "Clenck" took her into the kitchen and forced her to drink whiskey until she became sick.<ref name=made5232 /> The four men then took her upstairs, and Stephenson took a revolver from a dresser drawer and forced her to approach him at gunpoint.<ref name=made5232 />
Oberholtzer said the men took her to the garage and forced her into Stephenson's car.<ref name=made5232 /> Before they left, Stephenson told Clenck to stay behind and tell his associate Claude Worley that he was going to Chicago for a business meeting.<ref name=made5232 /> When they reached the railroad station, Stephenson and Gentry forced Oberholtzer onto Stephenson's private train to [[Chicago]].<ref name=made5232 /> No sooner had they entered the train's compartment coach,<ref name=made5232 /> than Stephenson grabbed the bottom of her dress and pulled it over her head.<ref name=made5232 /> He then grabbed her hands, tore off the rest of her clothes,<ref name=made5232 /> pushed her into the lower bed, and raped her repeatedly. He also bit her all over her body.<ref name=made5232 /> Oberholtzer was still intoxicated and unable to resist.<ref name=made5232 />
She finally passed out, after her attacker. Upon waking she said, "The law will get their hands on you!" Because his Klan connections gave him tremendous political power, Stephenson laughed and replied, "I am the law in Indiana." An examination of her body later revealed deep bite wounds were on her face, neck, breasts, back, legs, ankles, and tongue.<ref name=madgedeath>[http://blogs.smithsonianmag.com/history/2012/08/murder-wasnt-very-pretty-the-rise-and-fall-of-d-c-stephenson/#ixzz2T15QT5Fc "Murder Wasn't Very Pretty": The Rise and Fall of D.C. Stephenson, August 30, 2012, Smithsonian.com]</ref>
Following the assault, Gentry and Stephenson dressed Oberholtzer and told her they would be stopping in [[Hammond, Indiana]].<ref name=made5232 /><ref name=made5232 /> Stephenson and Oberholtzer, assisted by Gentry, checked into the Indiana Hotel. Stephenson forced her to say she was his wife so they could share the same room.<ref name=made5232 /> Stephenson forced her to write a telegram to her mother, saying she had decided to go to Chicago with him.<ref name=made5232 /> While Stephenson was sleeping,<ref name=made5232 /> Oberholtzer grabbed his revolver to kill herself,<ref name=made5232 /> but changed her mind,<ref name=made5232 /> fearing it would dishonor her mother.<ref name=made5232 /> Instead, she decided to commit suicide by taking poison.<ref name=made5232 /> The next morning, she convinced Stephenson to call Shorty{{fix|title=who?|date=August 2017}} and tell him to come to the hotel so she could purchase a black silk hat.<ref name=made5232 />
She bought the hat,<ref name=made5232 /> then asked Shorty to drive her to a drug store to buy some [[Rouge (cosmetics)|rouge]].<ref name=made5232 /> She bought an entire box of [[mercuric chloride]] tablets.<ref name=made5232 /> Oberholtzer returned to her room, but was still weakened from her wounds Stephenson had inflicted on her and only managed to swallow six tablets.<ref name=madgedeath /> She vomited blood throughout the remainder of the day.<ref name=made5232 /> Stephenson insisted that he would not take her to a hospital unless she agreed to go to a nearby chapel and marry him,<ref name=made5232 /> However, he panicked and ordered Shorty{{fix|title=who?|date=August 2017}} to drive them back to Indianapolis as soon as possible.<ref name=made5232 /> When he was asked what had happened, a bodyguard said she had been in a car accident.
Oberholtzer's parents immediately called a doctor, but there was nothing that could be done to save her. On March 28, she told what had happened to her in a signed statement.<ref name=made5232 /> She died on April 14, 1925 from a staph infection from the bites, plus kidney failure from the mercury poisoning. She was buried at Memorial Park Cemetery in Indianapolis.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}}
===Trial=== Stephenson was indicted on charges of rape and second-degree murder. The doctor who had examined Oberholtzer testified that the injuries she received were sufficient to have killed her, as her wounds developed an infection that reached her lungs and kidneys." <ref name="Linder"/>
Stephenson's attorney claimed Oberholtzer had committed [[suicide]], saying the rapist could not have anticipated her behavior. The prosecution countered that based on medical testimony, prompt medical attention might have saved her life. During the closing statements, the prosecutor decried Stephenson as a "destroyer of virtue and womanhood". The jury found him guilty of [[Murder#Degrees of murder|second degree murder]], rape, and kidnapping, and the court sentenced him to life in prison. The State Supreme Court rejected his appeal.<ref name="Linder"/> This case is still taught in law schools as showing an enlargement of the causal relationships that define homicide.<ref>See generally ''Stephenson v. State'', 205 Ind. 141, 179 N.E. 633 (1932).</ref>
===Aftermath=== The brutal attack on Madge Oberholtzer so outraged most members of the Klan that entire lodges quit ''en masse'', and membership dropped by the tens of thousands. The scandal destroyed the KKK in Indiana, and in the following two years, the Indiana KKK lost more than 178,000 members, nearly disappearing.
Denied a pardon in 1926, Stephenson started talking to the ''[[Indianapolis Times]]'', giving the names of officials who had accepted bribes and payments from the Klan. The ''Times'' investigated the Klan in the state. The state finally indicted several high-ranking officials, including Governor [[Edward L. Jackson|Ed Jackson]] and the head of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] in [[Marion County, Indiana|Marion County]]. Other local officials resigned when facing charges. The ''Times'' investigation revealed widespread political corruption, which helped destroy the Klan in Indiana and nationwide. By February 1928, Indiana Klan rosters had dropped to just 4,000, from a peak of more than 250,000 members in 1925.<ref>[http://www.indianahistory.org/library/manuscripts/collection_guides/m0264.html "D.C. Stephenson Collection, 1922-1978"], Indiana Historical Society</ref>
Stephenson was paroled on March 23, 1950, but he violated the conditions of his parole by disappearing around September 25, 1950. He was captured in [[Minneapolis, Minnesota|Minneapolis]] on 15 December, and was ordered by the court in 1951 to serve another 10 years. He was paroled on December 22, 1956, on the condition that he leave Indiana and never return.
In 1961, Stephenson was arrested in Tennessee at age 70 on charges of sexually assaulting a sixteen-year-old girl. However, the charges were dropped on grounds of insufficient evidence. He died 5 years later in 1966.
==Representation in other media== *Actress [[Mel Harris]] portrayed Oberholtzer in the TV mini-series ''[[Cross of Fire]]'' (1989).

{{Infobox song contest | name = Melodifestivalen | year = 2002 | theme = | logo = | semi = 19 January 2002
26 January 2002
2 February 2002
9 February 2002 | second = 22 February 2002 | final = 1 March 2002 | presenters = [[Kristin Kaspersen]], [[Claes Åkesson]] | director = [[Marius Bratten]] | winner = "[[Never Let It Go]]" by [[Afro-dite]] | vote = 50/50 Jury and telephone voting | host = | venue = [[Stockholm Globe Arena]] | entries = | interval = | opening = }} '''[[Melodifestivalen]] 2002''' was the selection for the 42nd song to represent [[Sweden]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest]]. It was the 41st time that this system of picking a song had been used. Five semi-finals had taken place to select the ten songs for the final, in [[Växjö]], [[Norrköping]], [[Sundsvall]], [[Falun]] and a Second Chance round in [[Stockholm]]. The final was broadcast on [[SVT1]] and [[Sveriges Radio]]'s [[Sveriges Radio P4|P4]] network. The introduction of the semi-finals and the allowance of songs in English resulted in a marked increase in voters. The final was watched by 3,720,000 people, with 926,318 votes cast in the final. == Schedule == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date !! City !! Venue !! No. of televotes cast: !! Heat |- | 19 January || [[Växjö]] || [[Tipshallen]] || 401,552 || Semi-final 1 |- | 26 January || [[Norrköping]] || [[Himmelstalundshallen]] || 310,727 || Semi-final 2 |- | 2 February || [[Sundsvall]] || [[Nordichallen]] || 219,111 || Semi-final 3 |- | 9 February || [[Falun]] || [[Lugnet, Falun|Lugnet]] || 331,731 || Semi-final 4 |- | 22 February || rowspan="2"| [[Stockholm]] || [[SVT Broadcasting House]] || 12,500 || Winners' Choice (Second Chance) |- | 1 March || [[Ericsson Globe|Stockholm Globe Arena]] || 926,318 || Final |} ==Semi-finals== The semi-finals for Melodifestivalen 2002 began on 19 January 2002. Ten songs from these semi-finals qualified for the final on 1 March 2002. This was the first year that a semi-final format had been used for the competition. This was the first year that songs were permitted in languages other than [[Swedish language|Swedish]], resulting in a significant number of [[English language]] songs, and two songs with lyrics in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]. "Ett vackert par", composed by Py Bäckman and Micke Wennborn was disqualified before the competition, when the dance band Grönwalls had performed it on the radio before the contest (not knowing it was supposed to enter). Nanne Grönvall and Nick Borgen was thought as possible performers. It was replaced by "[[Sista andetaget]]". === Semi-final 1 === {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! rowspan="2"| Draw ! rowspan="2"| Artist ! rowspan="2"| Song ! colspan="2"| Televotes ! rowspan="2"| Total ! rowspan="2"| Place |- ! revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2011}} {{demoscene}}
The '''Nullarbor demo party''' is a combined [[game development]] and [[demoscene]] [[demoparty|event]] in [[Australia]].<ref name='ecu'>{{cite web|url=http://ecumediaqa.ids.ecu.edu.au/popups/mrPopup.asp?mrID=748|title=Electronic art on show at ECU|date=1 February 2006|author=Edith Cowan University Corporate Communications|accessdate=10 January 2007}}</ref> The event takes place at the beginning of every year in [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]], [[Western Australia]]. It was named Nullarbor in reference to Perth's physical isolation from the rest of the Australia. Like other similar demo parties worldwide, it provides a platform for game developers and graphic artists to showcase their skills.
The event is supported by [[Edith Cowan University]], the [[Government of Western Australia|Western Australian government]], Perth [[Association for Computing Machinery|ACM]] [[SIGGRAPH]],<ref name='siggraph'>{{cite web|url=http://perth.siggraph.org.au/screening_20060223.shtml|title=SIGGRAPH Technical screening at the Nullarbor demo party|author=ACM SIGGRAPH Perth|date=23 February 2006|accessdate=10 January 2007}}</ref> Perth [[IGDA]], and many [[Video game developer|game developers]] (e.g. :[[Microsoft]] and Interzone Games), and is managed by Adrian Boeing and Martin Masek. The party is also supported internationally by demo scene groups from Europe and the USA.<ref name='support1'>{{cite web|url=http://www.demoparty.net/nullarbor2007/|title=Nullarbor 2007|author=demoparty.net|accessdate=10 January 2007}}</ref>
Nullarbor differs from many other demoparties: it does not try to keep the demoscene underground, instead it tries to promote democulture to a wider audience. Nullarbor targets academia, government and industry to promote game development and democulture in order to legitimize the scene. As a result, some of the demo entries diverge from the standard demoscene expectations, for example "Landscape Visualization", which placed 2nd in the demo competition, which were poorley received by the European demoscene<ref name='rdb'>{{cite web|url=http://www.pouet.net/prod.php?which=23989|title=Landscape Visualization|author=pouet.net|accessdate=10 May 2007}}</ref> which still retains a hacker culture.
Nullarbor is sometimes also referred to as "notrees", which is a play on the name 'Nullarbor'. In 2007, the event was retitled to "Interzone nullarbor 2007", or iz null in a shortened form.
== Competitions == The party includes multiple [[compo (demoscene)|competitions]], including but not limited to:
* [[video game]] development * combined [[demo (computer programming)|demo]] * 64[[Kilobyte|k]] [[Demo (computer programming)|intro]] * [[machinima]] * music * [[Pixel art|graphics]] * [[short film]] ("wild") / [[Computer animation|animation]]
== History == The first Nullarbor was held in February 2006. It attracted hundreds of visitors. It included only a demo, intro and game development competition, which was held at [[Edith Cowan University|ECU]] Mount Lawley. Teams from Europe and Australia competed in the competitions, including a number of interstate entries. Nullarbor was a breakthrough for the Australian demoscene, as the last demo party in Western Australia was the C party in 1994, which was 12 years before Nullarbor.<ref name="Cparty">{{cite web|url=http://oxygen.it.net.au/demos.html|title=Oxygen Releases|accessdate=10 May 2007}}</ref> The last demo party in Australia was Coven 2001.<ref name="coven">{{cite web|url=http://www.pouet.net/party.php?which=117&when=01|title=Coven 2001 Releases|accessdate=10 May 2007}}</ref> Nullarbor broke a 5-year demo party drought in Australia. As a result, Nullarbor attracted a record number of first releases and new demo groups. Game Developers that were also formed in order to compete at the event and added a significant contribution to the Perth game development scene, including the formation of new digital content companies.
In 2007 nullarbor was officially renamed to "Interzone nullarbor", to reflect major sponsorship by Interzone games. It became one of the world's biggest demoparties with over 10,000 visitors,<ref name='pcp'>{{cite news|last=Best|first=Timothy|title=Nullarbor Game Development Contest|publisher=PC Power Play|date=4 May 2007}}</ref> largely thanks to taking place as part of the [[GO3]] electronic entertainment expo and conference in the [[Perth Convention Exhibition Centre]].<ref name='go3'>[https://web.archive.org/web/20061217023634/http://www.go3.com.au/html/competitions.html ]</ref> Some sources report up to 30,000 visitors.<ref name='scene.org'>{{cite web|url=http://www.scene.org/discussnews.php?item=339 |title=news |publisher=scene.org |date=5 April 2007 |accessdate=19 October 2009}}</ref> The nullarbor competition expanded in 2007 to include animation, pixel art, and music competitions.
The 2008 competition saw a return to the traditional [[demoparty]] style taking place at The Bakery art venue in [[Northbridge, Western Australia]]. The competition was also extended to include a pitch competition and allow for [[machinima]] entries.
Australia obtained a second demoparty in 2007, the [[Syntax Demoparty]] in Melbourne, and as of 2008 Perth has had a strong presence in the Local and [[Global Game Jam]] events. Subsequently Nullarbor events have not been held since 2009.
== Events == # ''nullarbor 2006'' (23 February 2006) # ''Interzone nullarbor 2007'' (30 March 2007 – 31 March 2007) # ''nullarbor 2008'' (15 August 2008 – 16 August 2008)
== In the press == * [http://www.notrees.org/media_coverage/ Nullarbor media coverage]
==See also== * [[List of demoparties]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
